text:
Assuming she isn't brainwashed. Anyone can stand up and memorise scientific facts and say "there needs to be change". You have to provide proper solutions on how you can transition from non-renewable sources of energy to renewables gracefully in a way that won't hurt the economy. If radical change takes fold then the economy suffers, as a result people's livelihood's are lost.

Also making ordinary people feel guilty about climate change isn't a smart way to lead change. The ordinary folks aren't the ones who decide how the economy is run, they have more short-term priorities such as putting food on the table, ensure their mortgage gets paid off and taking care of their families. Not everyone is privileged as Greta who has the means to do what they are doing. Sure we can all do the small things like recycle where possible but our actions are pointless in relation to the actions of those running nations and corporations. 

On top of that, the whole climate change movement has been politicized only to hurt the ordinary people by getting them to pay higher taxes in the name of "helping change the climate". I can't side with something turned into a gigantic scam.

text:
If you still have doubts about the action part:
1 Stop eating meat and become vegan or as close as possible within 3 years (it's a guess, but you need to start now).
2 Stop wishing and buy not important stuff.
3 Don't buy products from dubious sources, nor to support politicians and businessmen blindly, always be suspicious and check where the products and services consumed come from, if the "ecological stamps" have origins and if they are not fake.
4 While you training this changing of life style, think how you could dedicate a bigger part of your life and time for this cause.
If we do not do this, life on Earth may be extinct within 7 or 27 years - another guess, because I am still studying, but I swear it is not an exaggeration, it can be more or less around this. If we think about it a person can take about 3 or 4 years just to change consumption habits. And why do I say that? Because the mega companies and governments only act on our demand, they do not do more than what the population asks for, with exception of some very rare politicians and businessmen that are responsible. Think about it (ps: the covid pandemic is just one of the environmental disasters we could have, it's not the worst and it was predicted)

text:
Co2 is not a pollutant, it's just a really good way to control people. Oil isn't running out, it's bio mass fuel so the more Co2 is available, the more bio mass grows, and a portion of that is subsequently re sequestered. People aren't dying younger because of Oil, they're living 30 to 50 years longer because of what oil brings them. The Climate isn't changing because of us, The climate is Changing because it changes and if you think that animals haven't eaten each other out of existence or rivers haven't wiped out habitats or forests haven't burned without us, then you are  very na√Øve and don't live in the real world. 

More to it, Co2 doesn't even warm the world as proposed, it hits a saturation point very quickly where it stabilises much around the same temperature range the earth has had for eons. Think about how the earth used to have up to 6000PPM and life was booming, that even when it was still over 600PPM, there were giant bird/lizards roaming the lands, note that coconut crabs get bigger every year as more Co2 means more biomass means more oxygen.

Oil is a perfectly natural formation of our planet and getting useful energy from it and returning it to the earth's closed loop system is not harmful, it's beneficial. Our best practise is to make sure we burn it as properly as possible so we give out Co2 and Water and much less of things like Co1 or Nox/Sox which cat converters and cleaner modern power plants already handle.

If you begin regulating a country's Co2 output, then you can throttle their entire economy as Co2 is the only universal outcome of energy consumption, production and industry, the climate scare in effect allows the expert and political class to govern the world as one entity.

author: Purple_ latte

text: ¬†@Purple_ latte¬† While you might be correct that she did not write it i too find it hard to believe. If you observe it‚Äôs so obvious that it isn‚Äôt being spoken like it is her very own speech. There is barely any passion nor is there any indicator that it comes from her very heart but at the same time I understand it‚Äôs probably anxiety inducing to be on a stage in front of many strangers. However, as an autistic person myself with horrible anxiety and someone who has spent years growing up around countless different autistic individuals on all levels on the spectrum I assure you a lot of us would show obvious body language and clear signs that what we are saying comes from within as we are highly sensitive to many things despite the popular misconception that we are emotionless. This is not to say however that some people are not less empathetic or passionate as everyone from each and every group will be different but as a rule we are generally very emotionally sensitive. To add onto my statement about how autistic individuals have obvious body language nonverbal autistic individuals would especially need to use their bodies more so to communicate given the fact that it would be their best way of communicating and it has really helped me offer support to autistic people around me when needed. I hope this is enough of an explanation in supporting the other individuals argument about how Greta‚Äôs speech was not her own.

text:
so the climate crisis, is an actual cross border crisis which first took shape in the form of acid rains, now has become a matter of the greenhouse effect. look, knowledge rest upon consensus, however people will need a lot of money in addition to noble efforts, like yours, at raising awareness within intellectual circles around the globe. The vested interest spend a lot of money, still not to deny climate change directly but to highlight the uncertainty and lapse in our understanding and instances of discontinued participation like the US' exit from the Paris Climate Accord does not promise any more unanimous decisions, accepted universally across the political arena.. this is an area which requires governance on an international level based on ethics as regulatory principles while the institution itself will lead with best practices... in the absence of any meaningful action, we can anticipate nothing more than having to adapt our lifestyles within the harsher climate conditions of the future, whereas if we can mitigate, we can avoid facing significant population displacement, in terms of losing vital habitat, nutritious soil and urbanized coastal zones to the rising sea levels. Bill Gates is writing a book on climate change at the moment and I would wait for it, read it and review my own understanding of the issue because in his experience, he has already spent a lot of money into research and development of fission based nuclear energy or power generation which is much safer for the environment than burning coal which produces a lot of carbon dioxide.. 

you know what they say about extinction, that death is the end of life, but extinction is the end of birth! scary places, we are being led up to... better now than later... good luck! üòê

text:
All the development is on one side, and our environment on other. Forests are the treasure we all should save and cherish. 

Those who agree.. DO SOMETHING FOR ENVIRONMENT! 

‚óè Stop using those plastic bags! U can carry a heavier mobile all time then u can carry a 5 g cloth bag too when going out eah time. Keep the pre existing plastic bags which u already have in your cars, scooty so that whenever u go out u can use them. 

‚óè Store that RO waste water and use to wash clothes or water plants,  or fill in the washing machine or even mop the floor,  For 1 litre of drinking water, 3 litres of waste watsr is produced. Those who are buikding new houses should connect the ro waste water to the toilets.

‚óè   Its high time we start recycling plastics friends!

‚óè and the most often heard... plant a tree. Most of u cant due to lack of space or u r too busy to help save planet. 
U can at least donate to the organisations! A small amount of 100 rs. Also makes a difference!

‚óè Put indoor plants in house instead of air purifiers if ur air is not that polluted. U can put snake plants which are approved by NASA and they dont beed fertislisers, and water is only needed once a month at maximum. They are a little expensive, but thats a one time investment!
There are several other plants also which are of no maintenance.

‚óè Dont think that caring for environment is uncool or who cares and stuff. This generation may die happily, but the coming generation will starve to death! 

‚óè EVERY EFFORT MAKES A DIFFERENCE. Every drop of water saved adds a day to someone's life. Every tree planted adds to someone's breathe! 



PLS MAKE A DIFFERENCE..... WE NEED TO SAVE THIS PLANET!

text:
As a Pacific islander i cried. My ancestors been living on these islands for thousands of years. I come from an island just a few feet above sea level. We rely 100% on what we grow. Our high tides are becoming more frequent & more damaging. The taro is our main staple food along with breadfruit & bananas, but now most of our taro patches are becoming salinated because salt water is seeping into our underground water lenses making our only main source of fresh water salty. Fewer fish is also a major issue. Long droughts & frequent storms killing people, livestock & destroying farms. 
I thank this young women for speaking on such issue. ‚ù§Ô∏è

text:
Climate change is not from CO2
What melted the last ice age?
What froze the last ice age?
Was not CO2,  it was the sun, orbit, volcanism, or comet or asteroid.
92% of the greenhouse gas in the atmosphere is simple water vapor.
Chemical energy got man into the Industrial Age.  Does oil and coal pollute you bet.  It is way too expensive, we need a technology that gives us a Car that costs one dollar to go 500 miles, and is 5 minutes to charge back up.  Problem One is that batteries will never do it. We need super capacitors.  It can only happen with room temperature super conduction, Graphene doped with silver and boron.  Then you need nuclear LFTRs to provide the 70% increase demand load on the grid.  More than enough Thorium to last 5000 years until you perfect fusion, which the Ocean has a 1000000 year supply but look to the comets for more.  Science people did you know that the CO2 levels were 10000 parts per million and the Earth was a big Ice Ball frozen at the Equator!  What do you think the Limestone and marble is made out off?   4000 years ago how many grass eaters just in North America were putting out methane?  Try 4.5billion, one herd of buffalo covered an entire state alone not to mention the deer, wild Rams etc.  Number one polluter in the world is big agro.  50% of diesel goes into growing are food.  Not to mention the energy that it takes to transport and refrigerate.  We need 100 times more power clean and safe at 1/30 the cost.  Yup we are almost there but the Elites of the world do not want that. 80% of the taxes paid all over the world are energy related. Governments make more money on oil than the oil companies do, and have no liabilities, that the oil companies do.  Cheap clean energy is freedom.  23% of the cost of any product is energy, more or less.  Solar and wind are energy transfers.  Never get the power back that went into making them for solar unless used in space.  I want that energy transfer on a boat, RV in the middle of no where, but will never generate the energy it cost to create(the glass,aluminum,silicon, silver, and then the wind Turbine with getting the rare Earths for the generator noise and bird kills) Energy is the real money!  Science people not junk science, would love to have a debate with the fact that nuclear power has a million times more energy than a chemical bond.  It is 24/7 cheap clean , not the water based reactors of today a LFTR look it up.  Not enough rare Earths to create enough batteries to do 1/10th of what you are saying and would increase the cost of power by 200%. Nice for the governments to tax and make more money, no we need 100 times the power at 1/30th the cost.  Solar can never be more than 50% efficient and again never make back the watts that go into making them, same with wind, also these systems have to be replaced every 25 years the pollution then trying to recycle them is catastrophic for the environment..

text:
I like eating deer, they taste good. I like eating bacon, they're fun and cute and make good pets and then when they're a little older, you can eat them. You know what I noticed though? The wild animals in my area have no such care for cultivation or humane farming, they just kill, take, steal, destroy everything they can, not just to get their fill but they carry on going. 

Before you point your finger at humans, why not point it at wild boar that stop trees propagating and essentially cause deforestation by eating saplings? Why don't you point a finger at the wolves that'll eat and breed until they outpace the food stock then starve to death? Why don't you point a finger at the lightning strikes that wipe out entire forests only for new forests to grow without many animals in them.

text: Some people may look at environmental issues as just another issue but they don't understand this is a crisis. Everything we do or don't do right now will affect not only our future but, everyone who comes after us.We need to stop ignoring all the facts around us. Everyday we burn fossil fuels and wonder why our climate is hotter than ever. If we keep burning these fuels now by the time we stop, the damage will have already been done. Let's not forget about all the animals that go extinct every year because we can't stop and think about anything but ourselves. We cut down their homes, test products on them, and treat them like they aren't living creatures and they're dying because of it. If we don't act now what's the point of planning for a future. We need to stop being selfish and work on this crisis while we still have a chance.

text: Climate alarmists have been predicting that the end of the world is just around the corner for for over 40 years.  They've always made melodramatic claims with little evidence and their models have always turned out to be dramatically inaccurate.  Now they've propped up a 15 year old with Asperger's syndrome and who talks and reasons like a child to lecture the world and tell us yet again the world is about to end.  It's not surprising they would stoop to using a vulnerable person like this, but I still find it very despicable.  I guess if you can't get what you want using reason backed by evidence, then resort to deceit, coercion and psychological manipulation (things they've grown very adept at).

Late Devonian, 375 million years ago, 75% of species lost. ...
End Permian, 251 million years ago, 96% of species lost. ...
End Triassic, 200 million years ago, 80% of species lost. ...
End Cretaceous, 66 million years ago, 76% of all species lost.

Autumn Peltier a young water protector has also been on the frontlines and speaking on this. I've captured hope and positivity through the last strikes, and you can watch some beautiful moments unfold in my music video titled Freedom, which features both young activists. We're stronger together - the people are standing together there's power in numbers.

text: She is actually projecting her fear on us all. She is just a doomsday prophet. Allthough she is correct in that we need to start change now there is no solutions in what she is saying. Its just a dark future that sprung out from her depression some years ago. She had a period with depression and it was introverted making her stop talking and engaging with others. Now she has a extroverted one that forces her to do the oposite. You can tell by looking closely she is kind of forcing herself to do this. Like a robot. She is trapped inside her psychosis and not doing this of her own will. She is autistic with aspergers and in scandinavia they are getting bullied in school. The strike she started is most likely a feeling of wanting to impact the minds of others like others have impacted hers, but only negatively. Bc she has aspergers she will never quite understand the human race and she will never fully understand why she is doing this. She will most surtain fall into a depression when this psychosis loses its grip.  The moment that happens she will disappear and then, within months she will be forgotten. A normal person with no aspergers would never act out like Greta is bc a normal person would after a while have the social skills and self awareness to understand they were only projecting. Its sad to see how many people uncritically follow her lead. Like this Ted talk its more like entertainement. Like a very dark and not funny stand up bit. This is not me going after Greta. This is not me being a climate denier. I believe the science that backs up what she is warning us about. This is just me being tired of people being followers of everyone getting a lot of traction and fame. Greta is just another human being getting her 15 minutes of fame. The difference in Greta and the Kardashians are not that big. They are just on each side of the fame bubble. The difference is that Greta will soon be forgotten while most of the people in the audience in this video will not change their lives like Greta wants them to. People today are too comfortable to being able to change their lives to having less. And thats Gretas whole point but it is flying over everybodys head because she has become a celebrity. And thats a very sad thing. The message Greta has would have been communicated better if she didn`t take a year off and denied her fame instead of using it as a tool. The fame factor will be her weak point and the thing that will blur her message and lead to her failure. I predict that she will be gone by next winter.

text: I read somewhere that she wouldn‚Äôt like to be on this stage nor give interviews if she wouldn‚Äôt have to. there are other ways to raise awareness. At 16 you have a fragment of what really the world is, even with the aid of the internet. To me this is publicity, maybe for a good cause, but with the wrong means. I wonder what her parents drive, does she have electricity? What is she eating? Where is their supplies coming from? How are they produced? She used a train to get there. Where does its power coming from? Electricity...where is electricity coming from? Everything is linked. You cannot talk about climate change when all your life is surrounded by services that actually affect the climate (anyone in doubt do your research). on the matter of going to school or not, you‚Äôre not going to school just to become a scientist, you are going to school to educate yourself, to ‚Äúopen‚Äù your mind to knowledge. Whether someone goes to school or not won‚Äôt make a difference. The only person that gets affected from this choice is the person who made it. text: ¬†@ican'tthinkofanything¬† dude no offence but you're not being practical. Except Trump everyone knows that climate change is real and that emissions need to be controlled, but the actual doing part is not as easy as mentioning about the problem. I've worked in the renewables industry for 3+ years now, and I can tell you confidently that developments are taking place. Huge and meaningful ones. But it's not a one day process. Energy is the basis of every process in the world. 90% of the energy was sourced through fossil fuels. The numbers are dropping now. Improvements are taking place. The sheer scale of the problem is such that the results take their sweet time to come to surface. The Scandinavian countries are today powered by renewables to the extent of as much as 80%. Idk why instead of actually doing their bit by planting a tree each week or so,   people think just putting it on administration is the solution. We need to be realistic. Airplanes cause a lot of pollution. Doesn't mean we can even reduce the air traffic. Cars cause pollution. Everyone knows that. But not everyone can afford a Tesla. Money DOES matter more. That's how development is measured. Rest is all bookish stuff and philosophy.

text: Dear Greta Haters, First, deal with your issues that make you so incensed at a 16 year old girl with developmental disabilities. What are you so afraid of if she can be so offhandedly dismissed. Second go read the IPCC AR5 Synthesis Report on Climate Change. Don't say anything else until you read the report. Third now that your attention is on the correct subject (Climate Change not Greta) you will most likely support your hateful rhetoric with anecdotes, psuedoscience, and baseless conspiracy theories. This is a defense and seems to be the only defense you have against the feeling like you are losing something when the evidence speaks directly and rationally. But perhaps you don't believe in evidence. Evidence can be wrong right? Can the Evidence of 97% of the world's scientists be wrong? I submit to you the Evidence may be an estimation (because besides you, no one knows the future with any certainty) If evidence is not enough for you and certainty is what you are after and denial is your thesis, submit evidence to support your certainty that the IPCC AR5 Synthesis Report on Climate Change is a baseless estimation, pseudoscience, or part of a vast conspiracy. Please support these with evidence to weight your argument with certainty. Fourth, now that you so desperately have managed to explicate an argument full of vitriol, logical fallacies, and wild anecdotes take a deep breath and consider for a moment that you might be wrong and what if you are? What then? Is it possible for you to be wrong? If not why must it be impossible for you to be wrong? What, I beg you are you so afraid of and is your fear based in reality or (as I suspect) in your past? Fifth, Please deal with your issues that make you so incensed at me (and Greta).

author: Wes G

text:
¬†@Wes G¬† On the Water
Just as soils are changed by constant tread of feet or wheels, water itself is often changed by the presence of boats.¬†Studies on water quality and clarity¬†found that in heavily trafficked waterways, boats did have a noticeable impact. The presence of vessels seemed to increase the growth of algae and kick up sediments, both of which obstruct sunlight and spoil the water. What's more, deposits left from boats can change the water's chemistry, adding too much of certain compounds, like zinc and copper, or making an environment overly alkaline or acidic. A decrease in water quality is bad for both wildlife and humans.
author: O's Auto Glass

text:
¬†@Wes G¬† On the Wildlife
Given that boats are large, intrusive, and dangerous vehicles, it is not difficult for most boaters to understand that their vessels have negative impacts on wildlife. Most people know too well the story of the manatee, whose populations dropped drastically¬†after motorized boats began touring¬†their shallow habitats around Florida. Because manatees are notoriously slow-moving ‚Äï the sloths of tropical water ‚Äï they cannot avoid the exceedingly speedy watercraft, and collisions with hulls or scrapes by propellers often do fatal harm. However, propellers alone cannot take responsibility for even a small percentage of damage done to freshwater and marine wildlife.
In fact, a large amount of impairment to wildlife is caused by smaller, less noticeable aspects of boats. Chemicals used to clean, protect, and run watercraft often leach into the water, severely impacting the environment and weakening or killing the wildlife. Aquatic plants and animals have specific requirements for light, temperature, pH level, and more, and toxins from detergents, paints, petroleum products, batteries, and metals have disastrous effects on wildlife‚Äôs ability to survive and thrive, including cancer, mutations, birth defects, and outright death.
author: O's Auto Glass

text: People like you just like to blame China and India without ever checking the facts. You shouldn't first of all judge countries by the amount of carbon impact they have, since a country could be a size of a city or take the whole continent itself. The proper term should be per capita. The global average for carbon emissions is 4.3 metric tonnes per capita, whereas it's 1.7 for an Indian. You know what's it for US, or Canada? More than 10. text:
Ok Greta. 

I'm not here to tell anyone climate change or even that anthropogenic impacts on our climate don't happen. But let's get straight for a moment.

Our Climate Sciences are composed of roughly <200 years of established scientific research and maybe <2,000 years of quantitative observations. Much of which have been lost to time or melted into the works of so many others in this political BS session that has been the 'Carbon Tax' and 'Global Warming'. Used largely to scare the public and tax the people. But now we are seeing Climatological changes on Earth. But who is in the driver seat? Human's? The Sun? The Earth? Much of the Earth's climate cycles last over 20,000-100,000 years and weren't even understood or accepted until a few decades ago. For the longest time it was assumed Earth was always relatively stable. Now we understand there have been unbelievable changes to the Earth. All of which have occurred without the influence of Man. Degree changes that spanned 15¬∞ changes, not the 3¬∞ I keep hearing about now.


The point is; We know so very little about this spherical terrarium we inhabit. Unless you can provide a legitimate solution, not just point fingers. You're just another one in the crowd with a loud voice. Useless.

 So, I agree with you, sort of. But the truth is that the civilized world is on the cusp of a massive population collapse. And since our economies depend on growth, we are trying to bump the numbers through letting in refugees from third world countries, bringing in the growth while destroying our culture. We're about to find out just how the American Indians felt in the 19th century.


And in the end, Thorium nuclear reactors will make all of this moot, eventually. They are not a future tech thing. They just need to get past the disapproval of all the watermelons* out there.

author: L S

text:
¬†@L S¬† Public speaking is always going to be nerve-wracking for anyone who has just started, especially on such a big stage like this. You're going to be seeing a lot more of her and I predict that she will grow more and more confident as she gets older and gains more experience.

We don't know what is going on behind what we are exposed to and how her relationship is with her family. It's nice that you seem to care but in all honesty, there doesn't seem to be many others like her that speak so truthfully and bluntly. It's taken too long for someone to talk out like this and attempt to make changes. If that person comes in the form of a shy 16-year-old girl from Sweden, then so be it. Let's not focus on the negative aspects of everything and try to come together to support in whichever way we can!

text:
I watched her speech before the United Nations as well as her entire TED talk at Stockholm, right here, right now.  Wow.  First, this kid needs a hug, some serious help with her fear and anxiety about her future and LOTS OF LOVE.  I respect her passion.  

I‚Äôm thinking that filtering the message of climate catastrophe through a beautiful Swedish child is simply ...ineffective.  I think the message of climate catastrophe is much LESS believable, not more so, because it is now being delivered by a child with several serious mental health issues rather than learned scientific experts in the field.  I certainly understand the emotional appeal of such a messenger, of course.  As one who also suffers from mental illness, that is NOT MY POINT.  The fact that she is a child, IS.  Who is looking out for her immediately, here and now, let alone ten years down the road?

What is the purpose in having a child‚Äîa 15 or 16 year old child‚Äîtalking about an EXTREMELY SERIOUS ISSUE before a group of people we are hoping will take reasonable and appropriate actions to deal with it.  I‚Äôd much rather that those actions dealing with climate change globally are based upon fact and resulted from an abundance of sound reasoning than as a result of blatant, thinly veiled appeal to emotion.  That‚Äôs no way to solve our problems.  The questions she raises far outnumber the issues resolved in her address.

Gretta is simply another distraction that will prove disastrous to the efforts of global action for climate change.  Her presence detracts from the very reality she‚Äôs attempting to unveil by giving opposing viewpoints yet another thing with which to object‚Äîrather than cornering them to deal directly with the issue at hand.  Keeping the issue ‚Äúfact based‚Äù and free from theatrics‚Äîdriving inexorably towards real solutions using the factual, proven evidence and based upon reason is by far the speediest, most effective and most efficient way to go. üòï

text: I wish more people knew! Carbon forcing on the climate is responsible for about 3% of the earth's temperature change. The remainder is due to solar cycles. All UN predictions for sea level rise and population displacement for 2010 then 2015 have come and gone without happening but they have no contrition. US carbon dioxide emissions have flattened in the last 20 years but China is more than the US and all of Europe put together. The total carbon required to build wind turbines and solar farms is 110% greater than they could ever offset in their lifetime of use and they produce vast amounts of heavy metal toxicity in production with no plan for decommissioning. Wind machines slice and dice 6 million birds and bats each year, many endangered species. NASA satellite studies show that in the last 20 years 50% of the earth's surface is greener and increased its biomass at least 14% due to slightly warmer temps and increased carbon dioxide which plants need for growth. We are at 400ppm co2 in the atmosphere now, which is one of the lowest levels in earth's history. When flowering plants first evolved on the planet the earth was at 2500ppm co2 and there were redwoods and gingko forests in Canada stretching to the arctic. The Climate alarmist propaganda demonizes all climate scientists who are realists and study the facts and data. The push is to control our lives, not save the planet. To everyone who loves the planet, I suggest look at the real science and leave the propaganda mills of the politicians, main stream news, celebrities and especially the UN. Those are all very powerful people who have oppressed countries and vulnerable populations for centuries who are now consolidating even more power to themselves and the price could be your children's very existence.

text: In all of the climate change debate, this is the one argument which infuriates me. Look into it just a bit deeper and it becomes obvious that the opposite is true. Meat (ruminant meat, more specifically)¬†is calorie dense and contains everything that is essential for humans to live.¬† Ruminant animal meat is mostly dealt with in local/regional markets. (i.e.- less global scale shipping and all¬†associated emissions).¬†When grown in its natural state (i.e.- grazed and not factory farmed), it creates a rather natural cycle with the land it grazes on. Given all the land we dedicate for grain crop growth, we could easily switch over to a system of responsible ruminant animal farming that is sustainable.Vegetable and grain crops are much less calorie/nutrient dense (i.e.- you need more grams of it to sustain life).¬†Vegetable and grain consumption¬†increases the number of bowel movements in humans (i.e.- a greater stress on our infrastructure and water management systems). And the vegetable and grain markets are massive in scale (i.e.- large swaths of land are razed. Massive amounts of water are used. Natural ecosystems are displaced, and very large numbers of insects and small animals are killed. Pesticides, even organic ones, are relied upon to grow the plants but pollute the environment. These crops are shipped all across the world, increasing emissions. Massive amounts of crops never make it to market, because they don't appear picture perfect. Most of the grain crops are used as the backbone of the processed food markets, which are deleterious to human health. Further, processed foods require factories for processing and all the associated emissions and energy usage.)As for the health aspects of veganism vs meat eating, once you equalize for life style (i.e.- taking smoking, drinking, and processed food consumption into account), one does not appear to be any healthier than the other in a statistical sense. As for the idea that vegetables and grains are required for health, this is hotly debated topic at the moment...with much of the data leaning towards carnivore diets being mechanistically healthier for humans.The point here is, 'going vegan' to help the environment doesn't make any logical sense. It seems to me that vegans are proselytizing and adjoining themselves with climate activists with cherry picked, poorly constructed studies to further their stated position of being morally correct.
author: L Mat

text: A single cow is fed for years and then killed for food. What can feed more people, one cow or several years' worth of crops that we're need to raise the cow? It's so obvious that veganism is far far far far more efficient at feeding people and we can reduce agricultural land by 70%. A cow eats more than a person
author: Ping Pong Cup Shots

text: ¬†@Ping Pong Cup Shots¬† We've got enough problems with the environment, and now vegans...

text: ¬†@L Mat¬† Poor vegans rarely understand how agriculture works, and that in many areas grazing livestock is the only way to feed local population. Did they ever touch a real cow in their life?
author: Guess Who

text: ¬†@Your Daddy¬† Funny that, you're implying that livestock animals are actually even able to eat grass and hay at all anymore.

author: Guess Who

text: @Ping Pong Cup Shots¬† Read what I wrote again. The important factor here you're not considering in your reply is the point about these ruminant animals grazing in a natural way. I agree that factory farming of animals is not a good way to go about it. Factory farms feed them grains (not their natural food) and then try to handle the health consequences with antibiotics. These animals are built to eat grass. text:
Biggest and most immediate things we can practically do to save the earth:

1) Plant trees. Trees act as a carbon sink that reduces the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. As forests keep getting destroyed, this carbon sink decreases in effectiveness, until it can't keep up, which it already has.

2) Switch to nuclear power. It's statistically the safest form of energy and has zero carbon output. Power generation is actually the leading cause of global warming, not meat production. Burning coal, gas and oil are the top killers of the planet.

3) Help develop electric car technology. Oil production and car emissions are both massive contributers to climate change. The faster we can get electric car technology good enough to be mainstream, the faster we can bankrupt the companies that do the most long-term environmental harm.

text:
The science is clear, molecules like C02 (carbon dioxide) and CH4 (methane) absorb infrared radiation where molecules like O2 and N2 do not. As we emit more greenhouse gases, we absorb more energy from the sun (rather then passing through and reflecting off the surface of the earth). There is no coercion, no conspiracy -- just people who cannot comprehend basic chemistry. The reason science is effective is because it is testable and verifiable, therefore claims made are generally true, unlike propaganda. 



The effects of global warming are uncertain, but knowing that temperature increase is real, I'm curious as to your reaction when 4 billion of the global poor begin to move to Europe, USA, Canada, and Russia (all rich-white countries) for your failure to take the situation seriously. That's the real risk perpetuated by climate change.

text:
Rick James   You don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a relatively easy fix to rid the planet of excess energy by developing multiple methods of amplifying radiation into space? 

And your doomsday migration/exodus scenario will most likely never come to pass. First, because the scenario is based on fairly sketchy extrapolations, but secondly, because martial law would have been instituted long before that. The ongoing game of migratory musical chairs will have stopped and people will have to fend for themselves where they are in many respects. But the most resourced and resourceful people will survive and thrive as has been witnessed throughout human history.
author: Mark Wheller

author: Mark Wheller

text:
¬†@Mark Wheller¬†  I'm genuinely intrigued by this comment, would love to understand more and don't want to get into the keyboard bashing that people love to online. 

If we agree that it is a problem and that someone needs to "figure it out", isn't the best chance we have of this happening to raise awareness of the situation so that more smart minds can turn their attentions to try and solve the problem? 

If I feel an intense pain in my body, I don't enjoy the sensation but I'm glad my body is alerting me to a problem that needs to be treated. Regardless of whether we find Greta annoying or not, is it not good that she's making the problem known so that smart people can start trying to figure it out?

So even if we don't think we ourselves can do anything about the problem, do we think the best use of our time is to actively criticise and take down those who are trying to do something about it?

I'm genuinely curious to understand what the motivation and rationale is behind that approach and use of time?

text:
A brave girl indeed. The last scence was heartwarming but a bit cringey, because all people who applauded will probably keep on living in ways that contribute to climate change, and dont prevent it. The girl herself raises awareness of the public on this issue rather effectively but doesn't really present methods to solve it, which is what I'm missing here. Therefore I'll just add a few brief things that everyone can do to live a more climate neural life: 

Don't fly and don't eat meat, milk, eggs or cheese. These things are all unnecessary. Especially the whole animal industry, that contributes to most of the green house gases (51%!!!).  Therefore we should get our priorities straight and make rational decisions. As a vegan I can add that a plant based diet is not just the best for the climate, but also the best for your health, in preventing and reversing diseases like diabetis, obesity, stroke, high bloodpressue, and cancer, which are however directly caused by the hormones, fats and cholesterol, found in meat, milk, egg and cheese... It might be worth adding that in a vegan diet, no living being has to disgustingly suffer and die for merely the stimulation of something insignificant and primitive as just minutes of simulation of our tastebuds, that's immediately forgotten afterwards anyways... 

Every claim in this comment has been scientifically proven.

text: She said we should give up meat and dairy, which are very nourishing foods, yet we consume a huge amount of non-nourishing, harmful foods or substances that require agricultural practices that are causing global warming, as well as many nourishing foods that are shipped or flown thousands of miles. These include chocolate, coffee, sugar, high fructose corn syrup, refined wheat, soybeans, modern oils made from seeds, indigestible and bee-killing almonds, tobacco, marijuana, wine, beer, coconut oil, and olive oil, all packaged up in plastic. And fruit, that is supposed to be some kind of answer to our environmental problems, requires a huge amount of pesticides. If we want to eat ecologically, we need to stop eating so much fruit, cook our own food to avoid packaging and waste, and shop locally, using the whole animal or fish in soups and stews. You can't compare meat and dairy, especially when they're pastured and locally-sourced, to non-nourishing and harmful foods and substances-these are what we need to eliminate, so we can save our soils, our planet, and our health. I get rye grain for my sourdough rye bread from a local farmer, who told me that rye grows better without fertilizer or pesticides, in contrast to wheat, which requires both in large amounts. Eat like your ancestors, and both you, and the planet, will be healthy.

text:
The real problem is electrical power. You cannot fix that problem with air or solar power. There is no infrastructure in place and such infrastructure would increase pollution and power consumtion on such a scale that it's not much of a solution to begin with. Air, solar and wave power production is not sustainable from a power grid perspective. It scares me that so many people in the business knows this and wont speak up due to the current social climate. It scares me even more when educated people doesn't take the time to read up on how the power grid actually works. 

 Oh fine EU could possibly put up a Sahara wide solar power plant and use brand new aluminum direct current cables. But that would mean going colonial again because of the political situations (plural intended). This also has serious weather related issues. So that's pretty much a pipe dream. 

 The only available way to currently decrease CO2 emissions in a meaningful way is to go nuclear for the time being. Then hope we are able to create fusion plants in the future. That or we can go back to a world without computers, TVs, cars, propeller ships and back to a world with wide scale famine and sickness. You'd need to kill at least half of the worlds population to do that. Will you sacrifice your family in order for the world to go back to the 19th century? I don't think so.

text:
Greta is very impressive and inspirational, but I think the main reason people are not doing anything. Is because they cannot agree what should be done. Basically we are following an entirely wrong approach. We have been trying to change the world through individual choice. We have tried to get individuals to fly less, drive less, eat less meat etc.


But this is simply the WRONG way to go about it. Yes we must also act individually, but REAL change can only be accomplished collectively. I am willing to fly using clean fuel. But to me as a consumer that is not a choice that is available.  An airplane could be fueled with bio-fuels or electro-fuels which are zero emissions. But as a single individual I cannot make plane companies offer me the green choice. It is a collective decision we must make. We must vote in green parties which will create laws to e.g. require airplane companies to  offer green choices. 


The second BIG problem with our current individual choice approach, is the freeloader problem. It is hard to motivate people to go green while everybody else is polluting. However people are much better at making the right choice if they know that others will join them collectively. If I was alone paying twice the price to fly green I may not have the motivation to do it. But if I knew half the population did it, I would do it, because I would not want to be worse than the majority.


We humans are conformist. We chose to better ourselves when we see others around us do it. When others don't, it is hard, only special people like Greta Thunberg who are great moral leaders will do that. The rest of us don't have that great moral standard. We need an extra nudge.

Man made climate change narrative is being pushed so much by the main stream media that I'm kind skeptic. 

NASA believes Antarctica is melting from below. Despite that there has been massive gains of Antarctica ice sheet. So Antarctica is not contributing to the sea level rising, but it's taking 0.23 millimeters per year away. But scientist reached a consensus about sea level rising, so what is the cause?
There are scientist that disagree with man made climate change, but topics like this is pushed to the side, so I refuse to dive head in and say I'm a believer. We need more studies. 



Yes, I'm skeptic, but I applaud her determination.

text:
Climate change is completely natural. The Earth has been heating for the last 300-years since the last LIA. In fact so has Mars--which has also been heating for the last 300-years and now the Martian ice caps are melting. Are we to blame the farting Martians?


Carbon dioxide (CO2) lags temperature; it does not cause it to increase. In other words, the hotter the world becomes, the more CO2 is released from various natural sources. Read that again, the hotter the world becomes, the more CO2 is released from various natural sources. In other words, the entire premise of anthropogenic or "man made" global warming (AGW) where increased atmospheric CO2 causes the temperature to rise is flawed from the beginning.

text:
small things we can do to save our planet:
1. use metal straws
2. switch to renewable energy
3. stop buying plastic bottles/bags. buy renewable ones that can be used many times. take  reusable cups to coffee shops
4. go vegan, even if it's just a few specific days in the week, (this might sound weird but it actually does help)
5. save electricity. do not leave your phone charging overnight. remove plugs from sockets that wont be used overnight
6. save water (shorter showers)
7. take public transport/ walk/ go biking/ car shares
8. dont waste food. start a compost bin. (this can help reduce landfill + give u healthy soil!!)
9. try growing your own fruits & veggies or go to the farmer's market !
10. plant a tree
11. switch your google browser to ecosia, which is a type browser that plants trees for every search!
12. USE YOUR VOICE... this was another person's idea and i literally just copy pasted most of these. it doesn't really matter at this point who started this comment when our planet is dYiNg. if you can, please use your voice to influence others.

text:
Okay you clearly don't think about consequences, im on vacation now so im just going to talk about number 1. So for metal straws to be effective we need the majority of fast food restaurants (straw using companies) to use them, therefore they have to be transported from the producer with a truck (probably using fossil fuel). That's not the only thing. I live in Sweden, 14 years old. I went to Gothenburg (liseberg) and the've started with paper straws. Now since the straws has to be clean and contain no bacteria it WAS wrapped in plastic, and if we start to use metal straws they would likely be wrapped too. You see only because an idea sounds good in this case "reusage" dosen't necessary means it comes with no complications. I didn't even mention the metal production that will have to be assigned for this idea to work
I DON'T deny climate change but im quite sure that an impulsive metal straw exchange would bring more problems than solutions.
Thanks for taking your time to read!

text:
The students may "strike" for climate change, but the diesel school buses will still roll as usual, the teachers will still drive to school and get paid, and the school will still prepare lunch and then they will throw most of it away. It's a waste. The demonstrations will garner some attention in the daily news feed (Aren't they cute!), and then everyone will forget about them.
"Everything needs to change, and it has to start today." Ms. Thunberg and her young friends are welcome to change what THEY do, conservation and personal sacrifice of the comforts of the modern world are the first things that come to mind,  but to get everyone else to change they are going to have to offer something that is materially better than what everyone else has now. Predictions of doom are not working because people have been inundated with that from the beginning of time. Maybe they should stay in school to try and figure out what those changes that would be acceptable to most people might be.

text:
This has become a political movement now. No longer a scientific movement.

You started by using pictures and videos of polar bears to further your climate change campaign, but when the truth was that they are thriving you have moved on. Changed it to a child to build emotion. 

I believe climate change is real, i however do not believe we have any impact on it, nor do i believe the falsity's that have come to light from the climate alarmists.

Sea level rise, warming of the earth, ice caps melting. they have all been inconstantly wrong,

The sea levels haven't risen even a fraction of the amount predicted, the ice caps have melted on one side of the planet and formed on the other so there has been no deficit in ice and the warming trends do not match human carbon production. Going from them you would think that climate change took a few years off heating up and then re-appeared randomly.  

The scientists who were previously part of IPCC have come out and called it a hoax, Nasa ex-scientists call it a hoax, the scientific organisations who get funding have miraculously changed their figures over time to match the climate change agenda.

The "97%" of scientists which were actually a hand  picked group of 30,000 scientists who were the only ones who claimed man could have an impact through fossil fuels were selected. Of this consensus they were asked if they think we could have an impact, small or not, that can include a "i think" not a i know. 

The truth about co2...well its factually proven to increase the rate of growth that plants have. The more co2 the quicker they grow and thrive, they use less water as well due to co2. 

co2 comes from our oceans, volcanoes thousands of natural areas. We contribute 3%, so you are saying that if a few volcanos were to erupt,and they will. They will cause more damage than man kind, its false. 

The fact that extinctions have happened... do we expect no species to become extinct, do we have dinosaurs still? No we dont, that is nature and its adapt or die.

Plastic and waste is the real issue across the world, not climate change. 

You can find that the predictions made havent come to light, so the alarmists have now followed the trend on warming and re-fiddled their figures whilst exaggerating the impacts. 

This is a unproven theory that has been publically promoted by media, politicians and any climate analyst who gets funding from either of them. If you claim against it.. you are outcasted, you wont get funded, you wont get promoted. Because panic funds research.

The solution we are given? Increase in taxes.. increase in money spent. And in the UK in particular, the money made from this is NOT re-invested into solving the problem... and we know why, because there is nothing we can do.

text:
Dear Greta Thunberg,
I personally appreciate your emotions about the crisis of climate change, and I completely sympathize with your ideas. However, I would like to firmly point out that some of your statistics, unfortunately, are flawed. Specifically, I would like to target my response at the 5 minute and 10-second mark to the 5 minutes 20-second mark. Your logic is correct, no doubt about that, but your examples are out of date and unreliable. I would like to include some factual stats. In the year 2018, India became the fastest growing economy, as well as the most technologically advancing nation on Earth. India is set to overtake the Chinese economical status by 2040, and the United States even sooner, by 2035. India has also become one of the Nuclear Triad, and also has the capability to target foreign satellites, joining an elite club originally comprised of the US, China, and Russia. Also, the Indian Sanitation Program has made great leaps in rural areas and has cleaned up relatively most of India, only to mention a few. Therefore, for these reasons and beyond, I beg to disagree and ask to change the mention of the nation India from the list of poor nations.

text: There is a 100% certain human-caused fingerprint in ocean acidification, because that is a chemical reaction and the extra carbon has an isotope which can be directly linked to human sources like power plants. The proof for atmospheric warming is a little bit less because it is a physics effect, but it matches exactly the carbon that makes the oceans acid. Sadly, the human-caused heating is releasing extra natural carbon and methane on top of this, so that past a window for action unmanaged heating will become inevitable.

author: Aaron Lee

text:
Aaron Lee Yeah people expect big changes because the world needs it but it‚Äôs not with one perfect human that we‚Äôll save this planet. It‚Äôs with a million small action. So you don‚Äôt need to become vegan, or even vegetarian if you can‚Äôt. You don‚Äôt need to go zero waste if that‚Äôs hard to realize at this time of your life. Just try to cut down on meat and dairy as much as YOU can. Try oat milk if you want. Maybe skip takeouts tonight and use the money you saved to go the extra mile for bulk shopping with your own containers. Those are suggestions but you don‚Äôt have to do them. As long as you‚Äôre doing what you can, I‚Äôm proud of you and it is enough, I promise. You can‚Äôt go from a typical modern day lifestyle to vegan and zero waste overnight but slowly, at your rhythm, do more and more and if everyone did that, I swear this entire planet would be a better place



I don‚Äôt know anything about you but I see that you‚Äôre watching this Ted Talk. You want to help. I know you can. I know you‚Äôre already trying. That‚Äôs great. Keep up the good work!

author: Mark Wheller

text:
¬†@Mark Wheller¬† you could argue this girl isn't correct or something, but if you're claiming climate change is a hoax, then explain why the fire rates in the amazon rain forest are at an all time high in human history, as projected by NASA. Even if it is a hoax, let me give you this analogy;


There are a bunch of people a flight and even some flight attendants that say the plane is going to crash. Even if the people are lying, shouldn't the pilot steer on the side of caution? It's our survival. We know there is at least a small chance that they are right, so even if there is only a 1% chance that tens of millions of people will be killed, shouldn't you reduce that number as much as possible? Any number measurably above 0% when it comes to our survival is too high.
author: i_am_anxious 02

text: Pi is the best   Climate change has always had a positive impact on humanity. It forces us to adapt and become resourceful. Humanity will easily figure out how to disperse the extra energy in our atmosphere. Climate change is real enough but ultimately will have about the same impact on us as Y2K.
author: Mark Wheller

text: ¬†@Mark Wheller¬† we're on a ticking time bomb that'll kill tens of millions of people if we don't solve it in time, and we already know the solutions and they just aren't being implemented (so "we'll figure it out" is true but it means nothing), and many countries are probably already past the tipping point. We know the solutions, and we are just to lazy to apply them. That's the entire point of this speech among other stuff. It is a humiliating struggle. It won't have a positive impact on things, especially because it's already set a rain forest on fire, so I don't see your point.
author: i_am_anxious 02

text: Pi is the best   Humanity is not at all threatened by losing tens of millions of people. There are always natural events which cull populations. And before you say climate change is not natural, it is of course. Humanity and all its activities are entirely a part of the natural world. We could not be otherwise. So ‚Äúman-made climate change‚Äù is just as natural as ‚Äúvolcanic climate change‚Äù or   ‚Äúasteroid-induced climate change.‚Äù In the end, it‚Äôs all a part of the earth‚Äôs natural history. Your fearmongering, while honest, is ultimately irrelevant.
author: Mark Wheller

text:
¬†@Mark Wheller¬† so you're fine with losing tens of millions? If a shooter is so good at shooting he kills the entire population of several small countries before being executed, that's also natural, because humans are part of the natural world. So a shooter killing millions is just as natural as a volcano killing people or an asteroid, therefor we shouldn't stop shootings?


The entire point of the climate change movement is that we want people not to die. And even if you're such a psychopath that you just view them as data points on a graph rather than people with valuable lives and emotions worth saving, in which case modern medicine and safety in schools and ect. is all worthless, it makes everything a lot worse off for the rest of us. It makes it harder to grow food and raise farm animals, it increases water shortages and droughts, and decreases farmland and living space by swallowing coastlines in water, as well as changing weather patterns. 


Yes, it's natural, with your corrupt ideas, but that doesn't mean it's good. And if something is bad, kills people, and makes everyone else's lives harder, natural or not, I doubt we should just let it happen, or take it lightly like another bump in the road, like you're saying here, not if we can do something about it.
author: i_am_anxious 02

text: ¬†@i_am_anxious 02¬†   Tens of millions of people dying is your scenario, not mine. I'm simply saying if it does occur, it will be natural and the human species will not even be remotely threatened by such a loss. My belief is that we will figure out how to dissipate the extra energy in our environment long before that. It's a fact that climate change spurs ingenuity and resourcefulness and that these dire predictions that you seem to buy into have much more to do with a lust for power and economic hijacking than the potential loss of human lives.
author: Mark Wheller

text:
¬†@Mark Wheller¬† the first half of your reply again seems like you're taking this lightly and objectifying people as data points, the middle is true but meaningless. We already know how to solve this thing, and it simply isn't being applied to the point where it's already caused drought and wildfires to occur more commonly than ever before. It's already slowed the productivity of humanity, and saying it's just randomly going to stop halting us even after the more negative long term affects kick in is absurd.


It should cause those positive things on paper, but in practice, no one ever does anything to stop this. In fact, we're constantly making it worse. A new report by the united nations says if we don't turn this around REALLY soon, as in, this and next year, we'll already be past the breaking point. The united nations already has more power than any other group of people, and they have no reason to hijack economies. The first is objectively morally incorrect, because you're ignoring the fact that humanity being unfazed as a whole doesn't make it an overall good event, the middle is ignoring the problem, and the end is simply propaganda, especially when someone like the UN gets involved.
author: i_am_anxious 02

text: Pi is the best   1. Nature is amoral. 2. I‚Äôm saying we can solve the problem through ingenuity WITHOUT changing our current behaviors or levels of consumption. 3. It‚Äôs already been exposed that the GND is a way to introduce broad based socialism into the US. The UN has similar goals which is why the UN despises the United States and our indomitable capitalism. I‚Äôm skeptical of anyone who rests their beliefs on arguments by authority. It doesn‚Äôt matter what anyone, expert or not, claims about a problem. They‚Äôre either right or they‚Äôre wrong. Unfortunately, lacking even one iota of necessary skepticism regarding our supposed pending doom, you‚Äôre wrong.
author: Mark Wheller

text: ¬†@Mark Wheller¬† I don't care what nature says about the problem. The thing is, if people are dying, you can't say "no big deal" because nature says so. People are dying, and so if nature is immoral, screw what nature says in this case. As for that second point, even if you're right, we could already be too late. It's already negatively affecting us.  And the third paragraph is not only propaganda, it also doesn't explain why other countries all around the world are studying their emissions and encouraging their own nations to reduce emissions and not even mentioning us. I'd also like to see a source on the broad socialism bit or any proof on why the un has similar goals.

Greed and jealousy.
author: Mark Wheller

author: i_am_anxious 02

text: Pi is the best   I never claimed to be a valid source for anything. I‚Äôm not here to intentionally change people‚Äôs beliefs. I‚Äôm saying I‚Äôm comfortable with the research I‚Äôve done to develop my opinions. If you‚Äôre interested, you are certainly free to tread many of the same paths of knowledge that led me to my conclusions.
author: Mark Wheller

text: ¬†@Mark Wheller¬† I like how you just shrug off everything I said and just say "I'm not here to change your mind" when that's clearly what you're here to do. And no, I'm not interested, because at this point you're simply neglecting replying and saying that I can do research if I want despite having no idea where to start. You literally just said things that would usually require a source to prove credible, and when I asked for one you basically said "they are like this because they act like this."
author: i_am_anxious 02

text: Pi is the best   I‚Äôm not trying to educate or indoctrinate everyone on the internet. You‚Äôre straw-manning an argument about my intent even though you have no facts regarding my intent. I‚Äôm very Libertarian in that I think all ideas are worth exploring and that you can have whatever ideas you choose. I‚Äôm simply confident in my beliefs and I‚Äôm willing to share them (not impose them) with anyone who might be even marginally interested.

text:
Given that access to cheap reliable plentiful energy from fossil fuels over the past 100 years has resulted in:  

-Doubling of lifespan;

-8 times the population to 8 billion worldwide;

-Eradication of malnutrition and starvation; and,

-11 times real income lifting us out of the grinding poverty that has been the human condition for all of history.

Given that the carbon tax is intended for Canada to meet obligations under treaties that target Fossil Fuel Emissions such as Paris Agreement. The aim is to reduce emissions to 95% below 1995 emissions by 2050.

Given that greater than 80% of global energy requirements will be met by fossil fuels into 2050 it follows that if we actually do meet those emissions targets that means GDP cut by 95% too. 

There is no reasonable expectancy to replace energy from fossil fuels with renewable energy sources. Wind turbines, solar panels and the like are not scalable to produce enough energy to meet demands, particularly when it comes to key industries such as making steel, concrete, and fertilizer. Further wind turbines and solar farms really are bad for the environment.

The only conclusion is that Carbon tax is about choking off our freedom by reducing access to cheap reliable plentiful energy.

The statement oft heard is 'what kind of world do we want for our children?' The question is intended to conjure up a world that has been rendered unlivable by our use of fossil fuels, despite the fact there is no evidence that rising levels of Carbon Dioxide in the atmosphere pose a threat to the climate. If you think it through you will find the green agenda will result in a world where your children will experience:

-Half of the current life expectancy;

-Reduction in global population due to famine, social unrest, and war until the ability to produce food without fossil fuels is balanced with the population ... that means a decrease to less than 1 billion people world wide; and,

-Real income will drop to about $300 per month.

Are you angry enough yet to get rid of the politicians who are pushing the green agenda with the delusional climate change alarmism?

text: The biggest problem now is that almost all the decarbonisation effort is going into intermittent renewables, and this effort has failed so far and is doomed to fail due to technical limitations that cannot be overcome. Sweden had shown how it is possible to reduce emissions rapidly using nuclear power. In fact the only successful rapid decarbonation programmes have involved either nuclear and/or hydro. There is a reason for that. They are the only very low emission energy sources that provide reliable energy. Hydro is more dangerous and far worse for the environment that nuclear, and not all countries have enough damnable rivers. Intermittent sources (solar and wind) cannot do this, and are far more damaging to the environment, because of huge environmental footprints

text:
How can we 'stop emissions'?
The problem isn't "the people" like we've been made to believe for decades: 
Apparently it's the women's fault for using too much hairspray (yes, that was a popular argument), 
it's our fault for driving cars, 
it's our fault for buying non-sustainable products, 
it's our fault for supporting exploitative agricultural systems in third world countries...


But nobody talks about the multi-billion-dollar corporations and their responsibilities (since they donate maybe 0.1% of their profits into "stopping" climate change, they can't be held responsible for causing 70% of worldwide emissions, right?)


Yes, we all have to cut back! Yes, we are all responsible! 
But don't forget that the responsibility of this modern phenomena called "climate change" is EVERYONES PROBLEM. 
We should hold those industrial moguls accountable! We DON'T have to buy what they're selling.

author: MJ

text: ¬†@Neptunus9¬† I advise you to educate yourself before you try to start a debate/argument over something you know NOTHING about.
author: MJ

text:
¬†@MJ¬† You are delusional. What I explained to you is how CO2 is measured in the atmosphere and how greenhouse gases, such as CO2, works in warming our planet. Those are not OPINIONS. Those are scientific established methods and definitions. If you want to dispute them, then you have the burden of proof.

If you want more evidence of Global Warming, I suggest you read the IPCC report. The authors and contributors to that report consists of the Worlds most prominent scientists, climatologists, independant organizations and authorities from the majority of the Worlds counties. 

According to the IPCC report, human activities are estimated to have caused approximately 1.0¬∞C of global warming above pre-industrial levels, with a likely range of 0.8¬∞C to 1.2¬∞C. Global warming is likely to reach 1.5¬∞C between 2030 and 2052, if it continues to increase at the current rate.

I am aware of Grand Solar Minimum. Solar physicists studies on this phenomenom shows that a recurrence of these solar conditions would not offset the expected rise in global mean surface temperature this century due to human activities. However, they do find a larger cooling effect from low solar activity on regional climates, particularly over Europe in winter.

You are in a up-hill battle, buddy. You are not arguing only against me but rather against the entire scientific Community.

If you can prove them wrong (and I honest wish that you were right), then the Nobel prize is yours!

text:
¬†@Maygan Phynix¬† and since you have no ability to do your own research and you require others to do it for you here is my knowledge I spent the time to learn and study.
In front,¬†hippos¬†have sharp incisor¬†teeth¬†and canine tusks that are used for defensive biting and for making aggressive displays. Premolars and¬†molars are flat-ridged¬†teeth used for chewing and grinding food, just as humans' premolars and¬†molars¬†are.
HUMANS Real carnivores' jaws move only up and down, enabling them to tear chunks of flesh from their prey.¬†Humans¬†can move their jaws up and down and from side to side, and we also have flat molars (which carnivores lack), allowing us to grind up fruit and vegetables with our back¬†teeth¬†like herbivores do.

text: ¬†@O's Auto Glass¬† Actually, vegans live longer, are less likely to get heart disease, diabetes, and most forms of cancer, they have less all mortality risk of dying.  Our organs and teeth actually prove otherwise, we have long intestines designed to process plants, and our teeth are designed for chewing food, which is something that must be done to absorb the nutrients from plants. The few hunter gather societies left eat mostly plants and very little meat.  The only reason we developed meat eating as part of our diet is as we moved to more northern latitudes plants were not available over the winter so we developed meat eating as a survival mechanism, which is no longer necessary since we can import vegetables.

text:
Greta is an amazing young girl, but she misses life experience. 

People don't act to save or defend something they can't see as a threat or a benefit. That's simply it. 

Single persons will care about climate change when their homes will be destroyed, they will lose job and their loved ones will die. That's how we work. Every measure in the human kind is a solution to a problem, not a solution to avoid the arise of the issue. 

We don't "prevent", we wait for the disaster, and then act on it. It's always been like that. 

That's why I don't agree when she backlash the solar panels, circular economies, ecc. That's the ONLY, and I really mean it, way to solve this problem before millions of people will die in urbanized cities as well (americans don't care about africa, especially true now that Trump is their president, and they are the biggest emitters).

text: Asking every single person in the world to give up meat and dairy is ridiculous and completely unattainable. However, what we can do is cut down on our consumption of it. Small actions have big consequences when everyone takes part. So next time you go out and decide to buy that burger from mcdonalds, think about the impact on the environment that burger has caused. text:
The solution is going to be hard, but it is also necessary. You make the statement that "people cannot afford that "(stopping emissions) but there is no choice if the human race wants to survive. Would we rather suffer through difficult financial times, or literally die along with half of the worlds other species. This is not an exaggeration. Scientist say 50% of the species we share the planet with will be gone in just 80 years, and do you know what is hit the hardest? Those at the top of the food chain, mammals. Guess what humans are?¬†
Agenda 21 was published in 1992 with full-scale implementation for all of the problems that you just outlined. It has been continually updated (now Agenda 2030) sustainable development goals. There was zero political will to implement the changes that were difficult then, and more difficult now. The longer it takes, the more difficult it will be, however, yes the changes and solutions needed have been long known. There was all the money needed to bail out the auto industry, bail out the banks and bail out the housing crisis. But it is always said it is too expensive to save the planet. If only a portion of the money we right now give to oil companies in subsidies was put into - say electric cars, they would be cheaper than the gas cars are now. It is the lack of will and the fact that the politicians are bought and paid by the fossil fuel industry that stops this from happening. 
I hear this argument a lot, and I ask, you worry that you cannot afford a new electric car, but the worry will change to you cannot afford food (need is expected to rise 60% while the planets ability to produce is dropping by 40%) and you cannot find fresh drinking water (Approx half the worlds fresh water is melting into the sea), then how important will the worry for the expense of a new car seem. A person can survive without a car quite a bit easier than without food and water. Economy and ecology must be balanced and for decades it has been out of balance in favor of economy, so yes, there will be a price to pay for our inaction. There is a penalty for in-action and now it is time to pay up. We have caused the problem and now want to fix it, but not hurt anyone. That is not possible. Thank you for posting real information to be discussed.
author: Tammie Morris

text:
¬†@Tammie Morris¬† Yes this! "If only a portion of the money we right now give to oil companies in subsidies was put into - say electric cars, they would be cheaper than the gas cars are now. It is the lack of will and the fact that the politicians are bought and paid by the fossil fuel industry that stops this from happening." 
That is Absolutely the most major factor in why we haven't changed yet. The people who are the richest pay to lobby and keep the system giving them money. We do not have to stay the way we are now! We can change, and in fact we Must Change! (Sorry, this topic, ahh, I get riled up.)

text: Obviously I disagree about cooling but unlike others here you suggest good place to observe apart from space weather, which I don't think is pertinent. local weather is good but myopic, look to polar convection circulation in the air and freshwater disruptions in the global oceans, big loopy jet streams that sometimes bring polar cold or participation to lower latitudes... volcanoes can affect the climate, crop production is good to watch, particularly the USDA crop outlook this year. Peep should pay attention to crop varieties as well and which ones are liable to diseases that are spreading. Anyone looking at coffee production in Central America is going to get a big insight into migration increase from there. Look at banana disease spread and potato and cassava heat effects on production. Red is safer than Burbank or Russet. Greenland isn't going to be the lead sea level rise contributor, West Antarctica will be, but even so all melt will lag thermal expansion. So knowing eyes will factor in subsidence, salt infiltration and look for coastal dead forests to signal sea level rise from aerial photography, which can also signal drought. N.B. changes in planting zones and species that are already shifting ranges. Finally, I think the ones who will implement public policy will be the military, keeping order in disaster zones. They won't be shutting down any coal plants but they do keep track of climate science because its already compromised two naval marine bases in the US and threatens many coastal bases. Look to public infrastructure rebuilding legislation and a knowing person will discern from that that climate change is real.

Majoritarian Nationalism narrative of a major political party is deeply affecting India. Sorry for that. Gandhi was great, there is no doubt about it. 
British rule divided the country. 
And Hinduism teaches about sustainable living since very beginning.  That is what the parent comment was about.
For eg. Sattvic food is what should be consumed by humans. It includes vegan diet +dairy, but the cow should be taken care of like mother, the calf should have had its share from the milk only then one should milk the cow for the dairy. But nowadays dairy is nothing but exploitation of cattle. This is not sattvic food, rather is considered sinful. 
We should protect trees and our religion teaches that by numerous festivals involving worshipping of different trees. (For the debatable oldest religion on the earth, its pretty scientific). The polytheism has most of its gods around nature only. Bapu (as we call him here) was a follower of Hinduism. 
Gandhi used single cloth (khadi, purely cotton) which he weaved by himself, grew his own food, had his own cattle. He lead a life what today is named as minimalist living. 
If someone follows Hinduism from its roots, it nurtures the nature rather than to  exploit the nature.

text: People who build infrastructure or grow food don't work inside. There is already a double digit increase in kidney dysfunction among ag workers in Central America due to increased heat and dehydration. Habitat loss is the present leading animal extinction factor, so there won't be time for climate grace for lucky species. Sea level rise saw a stepwise increase in 2008 and another after 2013, so it is not increasing at a constant nor predictable rate. Wikipedia says "The sea-level rise due to Antarctica has been estimated to be 0.25 mm per year from 1993‚Äì2005, and 0.42 mm per year from 2005 to 2015. All datasets generally show an acceleration of mass loss from the Antarctic ice-sheet, but with year-to-year variations." Those with math skills can observe a doubling time of eight years and shortening, meaning that we can expect sea level rise to increase dramatically in coming decades, even conservative sources like the IPCC are now predicting six feet this century instead of the 3 feet they predicted a few years ago. Finally, moving a billion people or more out of equatorial zones, and rebuilding fertile soils in Arctic regions is not something humans can do quickly, especially as it seems this effort is not happening now and the brand new Arctic seed vaults are already flooding. You are complacent about mass human migration and high death rates ahead, and you may live to witness how wrong you are.
