text:
Little things you can do to help:

Pull the cord out of the socket once you are done using the device. 
I.e If you‚Äôve been charging your phone, pull the cord out when it‚Äôs fully charged.

Lower your consumption of meat products.
The absolute ideal is to get rid of all meat, but if you can‚Äôt because of various reasons then I recommend: Avoid eating red meat(lamb, beef, pork etc), and if you were to eat it, buy the meat from a local farm or check where the meat is from. Have a varied diet, make some days of your week vegetarian or vegan. Many schools in my country have at least one day of only vegan food. 

Avoid fast fashion.
Fast fashion is what you call mass production of clothing, often in bad working environments and extremely bad for the climate. Two very huge fast fashion brands are H&M and Zara. When buying clothing check with the store/brand on where the clothes are produced. The best option to avoid fast fashion is to get hand-me-downs or shop at thrift stores, which actually seems to be gaining popularity with the younger generations.

Buy only what you need.
Think hardly before buying anything: Do I really need this? Is this really necessary or is it just because of aesthetic, self-satisfactory or popularity reasons?

Stop using plasting bags and other single-use plastics.
A plastic bag has an extremely short lifespan, mostly only lasting from the shop and then to your home. There are many other safer options than plastic bags such as regular bags, backpacks or tote bags(which also seem to be getting popular). Single-use plastics can range from anything such as plastic straws, cutlery, candy wrappers to plates. Replace that plastic straw with one made out of a reusable material like bamboo or metal, please reduce your consumption of candy and bring cutlery with you if needed.

Public transport.
As uncomfortable as it may be to sit on a bus or a train, it is a better option than to use a private car. More people sharing things means less production of said thing.

Please add to this list if you want to, we need more alternatives to better ourselves and save the planet.

The current scientific thought is that the Earth has about 5 billion years left. The lifespan of the earth is wholly dependent upon the ageing of the sun. In about 5 to 6 billion years from now, the sun is going to reach a point where its core can no longer sustain the nuclear fusion as it has been and it will evolve into a red giant. Therefore, that means the sun could grow large enough to engulf the earth, but even if it doesn't, life will still cease to exist on earth at some point during the sun's transformation into a red giant. There endeth the lesson.
author: Mark Matthews

text: Greta's talk brought me to tears several times. Not necessarily for WHAT she said, but rather the simple fact that this diminutive young teenager is wiser than 99% of the whole world and graced with eloquence and penetrating awareness of our current predicament. As regards her message, of course she is right on. I do wonder about the extent to which she understands that those who rule this world, the bankers, the oil tycoons, the military top brass, the top commanders of the secret space program, the top commanders of the global geoengineering agenda, etc etc ARE CLINICALLY AND CRIMINALLY INSANE AND, AMONG MANY OTHER AGENDAS, ARE ACTIVELY ENGAGED IN A MASSIVE DEPOPULATION AGENDA TO RID THE PLANET OF MOST OF US. Part of what I glean from her primary message is unfortunately "accusatory". That is to say, I feel as though we, the average folks of this world who work and raise our kids AND SO ON... are the CAUSE OF OUR CURRENT PRECARIOUS PREDICAMENT. And in a certain way she would be right. Her "accusatory" tone is, I am sure, more a call to action than an indictment. That said, she needs to wrap her mind around just exactly how deep the rabbit hole goes vis-a-vis the psychopaths who run this world and their army of complicit humans. But who knows? Maybe Greta will initiate "critical mass" to a consciousness that must increase if we are to have any hope whatsoever for real changes to the existing paradigm.

text:
Okay, well I can't keep silent either. I am going to step on the hornet's nest because enough is enough.


I am in despair at the comment thread here and so should you be. This Ted talk is emotional blackmailing, dissembling and crude propaganda. And you are buying this? You supposedly intelligent, educated and rational people?


Never mention climate change? You can't turn on the radio, television or open a newspaper, let alone go online - it's everywhere -and has been for decades. The BBC bangs on about it every chance it gets - which is every day without fail somewhere. Each year the IPCC tells us we have "only ten years left" (it's been doing this for about three decades now) and every MSM outlet screams it from the rooftops. No restrictions on carbon emissions? Are you kidding? Ever tried paying for a car in Europe? The green taxes are fully 10% of the cost - and rising! (yep, I get it, she's 11, why would she be looking at green car taxes). Obviously she's never been to Denmark where the whole country is one irresponsible, mega-despoliation of the environment by grossly inefficient and polluting windmills. And no Planet "B"? She's absolutely got to be wrong about that one because that must be where she's living. 


And what's all this about having a child advise the world about something which she has clearly only ever been fed one side of an argument? Why, because she's cute and got Asperger? How does that help? It's time to get real, think clearly and grow up folks.

text:
Yes, it should be in the headlines every day, at least every week!
I think the problem is hope.
People have the FALSE hope that "somebody else will do something about it".

And others get so overwhelmed by their LACK of hope that they decide to not think about the topic -- because it makes them uncomfortable, depressed, or even petrified, frozen by fear. If you're petrified, you can't act. Many might be wilfully ignoring the topic in order to be able to emotionally function in their day-to-day lives.

I think even if we can not stop climate change, we should at least commit to slowing it down. Because the slower it comes, the better people everywhere can adapt to the changes, which means, less suffering for humanity as a whole.

text: I definitely think it's admirable for a young person to be so involved. Yet she desperately says to want action, but is growing into a speaker herself. She says solutions are already there and now is the time to implement them in our life and society. We only have to act. I disagree on this point. I think it's difficult to find solutions and if we have them they are very costly. And if we have a solution, found a way to pay for we still need people willing to work for it. We should teach the young people that it's not always that simple and not applaud to them for skipping school. We should teach them how to solve problems so they can see how hard it is amd develop, not putting them on stage to amplifie the emotions of the masses. This is the task of parents and teachers. After all, why don't they demonstrate after school? Would that be too much action? Lastly, I'm not in favor of promoting alarmism (im any field) via children, activists and politicians. Scientists are there to inform us and they have a better understanding of the urgency of the problem and worked hard to come to this understanding. I don't doubt the intentions of Ms. Thunberg are good, but I would not wish it nor allow it for my child.

text:
The ship was sinking---and sinking fast. The captain told the passengers and crew, "We've got to get the lifeboats in the water right away."¬†

But the crew said, "First we have to end capitalist oppression of the working class. Then we'll take care of the lifeboats."¬†

Then the women said, "First we want equal pay for equal work. The lifeboats can wait."¬†

The racial minorities said, "First we need to end racial discrimination. Then seating in the lifeboats will be allotted fairly."¬†

The captain said, "These are all important issues, but they won't matter a damn if we don't survive. We've got to lower the lifeboats right away!"¬†

But the religionists said, "First we need to bring prayer back into the classroom. This is more important than lifeboats."¬†

Then the pro-life contingent said, "First we must outlaw abortion. Fetuses have just as much right to be in those lifeboats as anyone else."¬†

The right-to-choose contingent said, "First acknowledge our right to abortion, then we'll help with the lifeboats."¬†

The socialists said, "First we must redistribute the wealth. Once that's done everyone will work equally hard at lowering the lifeboats."¬†

The animal-rights activists said, "First we must end the use of animals in medical experiments. We can't let this be subordinated to lowering the lifeboats."¬†

Finally the ship sank, and because none of the lifeboats had been lowered, everyone drowned.¬†

The last thought of more than one of them was, "I never dreamed that solving humanity's problems would take so long---or that the ship would sink so SUDDENLY.

Daniel Quinn

text:
When I was a kid, here in the Italian Alps. Playing with snow was our favorite way of having fun in wintertime. Snowy playgrounds of my childhood!

In those days we had snow many times during the winter. It was rather normal to have some 40-50 cm fresh snow every week in December, January, and February.
I remember my grandfather shoveling snow off the ground for hours, while my friends and I had our good time playing in the backyard and went skiing down the slopes in the pine forest nearby.

Now everything is different here. Last time I visited my parents' house I've recovered the shovel my grandfather used... it was in the garage, covered with rust and dust, its handle no longer usable.. it hasn't been used for years  (last big snow was in 2000!). Now, we just have some 1-2 cm snow once or twice a season!! 

Even up in the mountains, our ski resorts now have to massively use artificial snow to extend the duration of the skiing season.

Such a great change has happened in just 3/4 decades. Global warming is definitely a great threat, we must take a stand to stop it!

We, adults, MUST listen to the voices of our children: It is not too late to stop climate change, but we have to act now! The snowy playgrounds of my childhood are lost for me and my generation, but it is our responsibility to give our children and grandchildren the opportunity to play again!!

text:
IPCC did a prognosis in 2003 about the Maldives .They said that the Island would be submerged under water by 2017. Nothing of this kind has happend. The "Rising ocean level" is non-existent. They (IPCC) now tries to spread panic about the CO2 levels instead, and ties it to the planetary rise of temperature (0,2 C. last year) Neglecting the findings of some non PC scientist, that earth temperature in the last 10 000 years fluctuated within "small iceage" (The last one between year 1350-1850) and year 850 och 1250 A.D. with considerable  warmer climate ( Wich made it possible to harvest wheat on Greenland, as the viking colonys did, or harvest grapes on the british Isles). As they say : we are in the middle of a natural fluctuation upwards trend, that will end soon and then the earth temperature will cool down again. 
What I dont know is why the consensus of CO2=rising earth temperatures would be a result of burning fossil fuels ? We have all the data collected. Earth temperature fluctuates as a natural phenomenon. What makes me nervous about the global elite climate alarmist exaggeration is that it presents an opportunity to form a world government acting as a  superstructure to dictate and expanding a power alliance of wich we ordinary folks dont know nothing about. Im highly skeptic about this ... If they use school children to get the message across, makes me personally think there is something behind it. Stir up emotions and the powerful will step in to "Fix" the problem, but ONLY if they are given the mandate to manifest radical measures..not only linked to the Climate, but in so many other fields of special interest for the powerful. It could very well be that we are giving a big chunk of freedom to these people if we give them a reason.

text:
Weird, why would a kid do this talk? Why is she not presenting scientific studies? Actual facts? Actual solutions? I don't think this type of fearmongering is bringing forward any significant change. Whether it's a kid that's doing it or not doesn't matter.

I definately think we need and could change things about CO2 production. But we need a good plan that a lot of nations can get behind. Something that is actually achievable. Nothing we've done so far has had any impact whatsoever and you can't go forbid people from flying, driving cars or using electricity (which are the biggest issues). 

Maybe the best solution is to invest in fusion energy production. That would at least make electricity production clean. But it might be too late, until we can apply that world-wide... And we need a lot of highly intelligent people for that, and it seems like we don't want intelligent people in universities these days. They want diverse people. Sadly, intelligence and skill has become secondary. So that's a big issue imho.

text: I don't find her annoying, I find her inspirational. And handicap? If she wasn't so honest, you'd not be able to criticize her. She speaks well - with passion and insight - and the fact that she readily admits to having an ASD is what you focus on? I see an intelligent, passionate, serious young girl who lacks ego or pretense - and you call that a handicap? She might have sensory or social issues you don't deal with, but she has amazing gifts and I certainly don't see her as handicapped. She's a different neurotype - and her bracing honesty is refreshing. Those with ASDs have given a lot to the planet. Don't belittle her social differences or communication style as a handicap when she's trying to generate change. And even if you don't believe in climate change, I think everyone can see that we humans are totally ruining our earth by our reckless ways. We are poisoning the air we breathe, the water we drink, the soil we rely on for food. As a species, we are myopic and foolish at best, deranged and insane at worst.

text:
Noch nie in diesem Jahrhundert gab es so viele wissenschaftlich Ungebildete Angsthasen. Sie lassen sich von interessierten Kreisen durch Angst vor vermeintlichen "Katastrophen" dazu verleiten die letzten Reste der Vernunft und des Realismus zu vergessen. Sie lassen sich von diesen Kreisen vor sich hertreiben wie eine Schar aufgeregter H√ºhner! Leute, bleibt doch nur f√ºr einen Moment stehen und schaltet das Hirn wieder ein: da Ihr, genau wie diejenigen die euch die Angst einjagen nicht in die Zukunft schauen k√∂nnt, g√∂nnt euch doch einmal einen Blick in die erdgeschichtliche Vergangenheit! Die ist gesicherte Zeitgeschichte und bestens bekannt. Fangt nicht mit 1850 an, sondern mit 100.000 vor Christus. Vergleicht das Klimageschehen von einst mit dem von heute: Ihr werdet feststellen war alles schon einmal und mehrfach da! Viel w√§rmer, viel k√§lter, viel n√§√üer oder viel trockener, mal f√ºr wenige hundert Jahre oder √ºber mehrere Jahrzehntausende hinweg. Egal ob mit Menschen an Bord der Erde oder nicht, aber niemals, nicht ein einziges mal war am Klimageschehen das arme CO¬≤ urs√§chlich beteiligt. Das CO¬≤ war vielfach h√∂her (was gut f√ºr flora und fauna der Zeit war...), aber auch schon niedriger  als heute. Das belegt das es keinen urs√§chlichen Zusammenhang zwischen Erderw√§rmung/Klimageschehen gibt! Lasst euch nicht ins Bockshorn  jagen von den Klimaaktivisten: sie haben nicht den geringsten Schimmer von dem was Sie an Erkl√§rung zu bieten haben: kein einziger Beweis, null Wissen, im Regelfall gegen die Gesetze der Natur!
Merke: Klima ist nicht vom Menschen beeinflusst/beeinflussbar

auf Englisch: 

Never before in this century have there been so many scientifically uneducated scaredyhounds. They let themselves be tempted by interested circles by fear of supposed "catastrophes" to forget the last remnants of the reason and the realism. They let themselves be driven by these circles like a crowd of excited chickens! People, just stand there for a moment and switch your brain back on: since you, just like those who scare you can not look into the future, yet allow yourself a glimpse into the geological past! This is secure history and well known. Do not start with 1850, but with 100,000 BC. Compare the climatic events of yesteryear with those of today: you will find everything has happened once and more than once! Much warmer, much colder, much wet or much drier, sometimes for a few hundred years or over several decades. Whether with people aboard the earth or not, but never, not once was the climatic events the poor CO¬≤ causally involved. The CO¬≤ was much higher (which was good for flora and fauna of the time ...), but also already lower than today. This proves that there is no causal connection between global warming / climatic events! Do not be scared off by the climate activists: they have not the slightest idea of ‚Äã‚Äãwhat they have to offer in explanation: not a single proof, zero knowledge, usually against the laws of nature!
Note: Climate is not influenced / influenced by humans

text:
Everyone commenting here:
I assume you care about the climate, otherwise you wouldn‚Äôt have watched the video.
So I‚Äôm asking you, are you just commenting how right Greta is and how we have to act? Or ARE YOU ACTUALLY ACTING?
I agree with Greta, the politicians have to start making more laws and restrictions. But we cannot blame it all to the politicians.

The BEST THINGS YOU AS AN INDIVIDUAL CAN DO are
- Take trains and buses instead of cars
- Avoid flying
- Stop eating meat and dairy (animal products are the main cause of rain forest deforestation, waste tons of water and produce co2)
- Avoid palm oil
- Avoid plastic (especially at grocery shopping)

& make others do the same!!

I went vegan 5 years ago and decided not to do my license and instead only use public transportation (I‚Äôm aware this is not an opinion on some locations) - so many people laughed about me, barely anyone took it serious. While I should have been the one not taking them seriously. Because they didn‚Äôt care. They were the ones ignoring scientific facts. Just because they were too lazy to do their own research and change their actions.
Now, I feel like people finally start questioning. Half of my friends are vegetarian or vegan, haters might say ‚Äúit‚Äôs just a trend‚Äù but even if it was? SO WHAT? It‚Äôs a GOOD THING! Lots of them also try to avoid taking the car whenever it‚Äôs possible, avoid plastic bags etc.

I JUST WANNA ENCOURAGE YOU TO ACT TOO! :)

text:
While she is doing great things and is obviously a very talented speaker, I must say she is exaggerating a little bit.  Climate change is most certainly real and is a big
problem, however efforts to stop climate change are getting better and better each year. She is instilling fear and panic into everyone, that no one is doing anything and we‚Äôre all going to die. She is also saying that we have all the facts about climate change, and we don‚Äôt need more researchers. In fact, now is exactly the time for more
research! Current efforts aren‚Äôt working that well, so we need more research and better methods! She is saying that no one is doing anything, in fact, lots of people are doing things! Vegan diets are on the rise, countries are beginning to cut their emissions, and more money is being put into climate change research. Action against climate change is exactly how we beat it. Not everything is as bad as she says, in fact, a paper last year outlined a new plausible way to beat climate change using a chemical reaction to trap large amounts of CO2. To continue our improvements as humanity, I recommend everyone to reach out to senators, the people in power, to put in place legislation to stop climate change! This can only be done if we work together as one united species! Again, not trying to debunk her, or undermine her efforts, just giving some optimism into the comment section because this speech almost instilled an existential crisis into me:)

text: I will say I have Aspergers syndrome as Well and I agree with what she says. My grandmother taught me a lot growing up even everything when it comes down to food. True I do eat meat and I do have dairy however I only eat what I need. I don't go out looking to eat everything. I collect a mixture of meat and veg along with plants and other sources. Depending on what I make, I will not waste it, I reuse it the next day or make it into something else to eat. As my nan always told me "we didn't have the luxury of buying food excessily in my day, we survived on what we had, we didn't waste and we could make anything out of everything and it worked, we had what was 'necessary' to survive and that's all that mattered". I live by those words, I live by everything she taught me. Big industries and companies need to stop making stuff that breaks down fast, sustainability in their products can help reduce waste complete. Also good parenting on youths today who are abusing the system because they have not got the educational background to help them understand what they are doing is wrong. Plant fruit and veg in the garden, grow your own food, have healthy plants in the house to reduce carbon dioxide. Don't use heating unless absolutely necessary. There are so many things that can be done. Instead of sitting back and saying I'll do it tomorrow, start today. This is the dawn of the future, a future for everyone.

text: ¬†@Kev Alan¬†well, it's not just about "yelling fire". The amount of land, water and gas that is used to make only 1kg of meat and to supply it is just far too much. What we need is more wildlife. More rainforest, more untouched areas, less riding the plane, less using cars. But most of all, we need plants. But by keeping an economy alive that is defined by surplus and waste, we get rid of those areas even more, as acres are still growing.
author: paraxsoul

text: ¬†@Nick Brown¬† even if this were true it doesn't explain the extinction of species or the death of many many insects, such as bees, that are much-needed for the pollination of plants. We've lost about 70% of birds and insects since the late 80s alone, that's alarming, even if the cause for the earth getting warmer were underground volcanoes. It's not hard to see that there is too little diversity in plants, birds and insects don't find food or a killed by pesticides etc. This also means that there are going to be less types of plants, which eventually means less plants altogether, which means more CO2 (because that's what plants transform into oxygen). CO2 on the other hand warms the climate. Leaving the aspect of a warmer climate aside, I challenge you to think about the other aspects I mentioned. I'm not looking to patronize you here, I just want you to think about it.
author: paraxsoul

text: ¬†@paraxsoul¬†  I agree with those points! But if we do as little Greta says and focus on CO2, we gobble up all our scarce resources for improving the world and throw it at the wrong problem. Animals are much more important than CO2!
author: Kev Alan

text: ¬†@Kev Alan¬† I'm not sure I understand what you mean. Livestock is just as much part of the CO2 emission problem as transport is. Sometimes it's even both, if meat or dairy is exported. Aside from that, it takes space for plants that are desperately needed to compensate already existing emissions. Of course you are not wrong when you say we should opt for new solutions. This however doesn't mean that in the meantime we shouldn't at least try to reduce our carbon footprint. It doesn't matter if half of the world becomes vegan or if meat consumption is cut down by half globally. It will still have an amazing impact on the environment. The fact that animals and insects are dying is also linked to how fields are designed. Monocultures don't offer a variety of food sources, so insects can't pollinate. Rapeseed is a good example for this, it's completely useless for wildlife. By cutting down the demand for meat we can potentially create new overgrown wildlife areas (namely there were livestock feed used to be grown), which doubles as a food source for animals and insects as well as transforms CO2. So it's a mixture of several different aspects, really.
author: paraxsoul

text:
This Is The Major 
I have reduced carbon footprint (both personal & business) from 100 lbs of CO2e per day to 65. It‚Äôs not much, and it‚Äôs not enough, but it‚Äôs progress. I also recently moved to a smaller house and shop in an area with a milder climate, which will drastically reduce my heating & cooling emissions, plus I get a larger % of my power from renewable sources here. I haven‚Äôt been collecting data here long enough to accurately calculate how much difference this has made, so the 65lbs/day figure is from before the move. Likely less than 50lbs/day here.

TL;DR: I‚Äôve cut my greenhouse gas emissions in half since this comment.

Edit:
I realized you might ask what changes I made...most of that reduction came from simply cutting back electricity usage (wearing a hoodie instead of heating the house as much, taking shorter showers, driving less) and quitting meat. Still about 80% of my emissions are from electricity (half of that is charging an EV) so I‚Äôm definitely working to reduce that.

text:
Which example of Correlation is proof of causation?
1) Increasing level of  CO2 in greenhouses to 600ppm increases fruit yields
2) Shark attacks in summer show a direct correlation with ice cream consumption.
3) Lowering CO2 in greenhouses to 150ppm causes plants to die
4) Lower temperatures during one ice age period were directly caused by higher atmospheric CO2
5) Higher  temperatures during an interglacial  period is directly caused by lower atmospheric CO2
6) World trade and travel increase with zero CO2 emissions .
7) The more people who pledge to have no children, the less world climate will change.
8) Ambient temperatures in rainforest are consistently much cooler than open plains 
9) Wealth and life expectancy relate to physical exercise (not energy availability)
10) The more people who demonstrate the more truth to global warming.
11) The more funding made available to climate groups, the more evidence we‚Äôll have that its true.
12) The more Ms Thunberg strikes fear into our youth, the more anarchy  and Hong Kong like strife we‚Äôll see.

text: eviken1982 Not sure what you mean with ‚Äúthey‚Äù. I took your advice and researched on it. Scientists are actively studying the impact of the active volcano on the melting. I think there is a misunderstanding about what is meant by saying ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù. It is NOT the fact that the temperature is rising. It is about the rate it is rising. No scientist ever said that the only cause for it is the greenhouse gas emission. That wouldn‚Äôt be science. There are always many different phenomena that contribute to a global change. However, the emission of greenhouse gases seem to be a major factor for the speed of warming, based on data analysis and modeling. Does science ever claim this is the only possible truth? No. Is it the truth that fits most consistently with as many observed data as possible? Yes. So to come back to your claim: The sun activities and volcano activities sure contribute to warming. But if you solely take them into account, it just does not add up to the effect we are measuring.

text: She sums it up from 0:41 - 0:48 If it was an issue we would be doing something about it. Problem is it's not an issue and CO2 is not the problem obviously as it keeps going up and temperatures aren't rising. There is no climate catastrophe, we continue to be well under the so called expert predictions and we've done nothing to change the climate. If she was so concerned maybe she would do more research and ask questions like why do NASA and NOAA change past temperature data. Why should we not let poorer countries develop like western countries have using fossil fuels which will extend their life expectancy and give them a better quality of life like it's done for us? Why is it that all the predictions of doom and gloom haven't happened? How many tipping points do we need to pass to realize it's not happening? I feel sorry for those who are so gullible who get sucked in to an emotional response to "take action". You're being told that CO2 is a climate control, reduce it and things will be better. It's 0.0410 which is a really tiny number when your factoring in water vapor, hardly anything will change that, it's basic chemistry. It's like the equivalent of 2 people in a stadium of 100,000. It's that minuscule.

text:
You don't have to do everything all at once... but we ALL need to start right changing NOW. Look at your consumption habits - let's not forget that the gas, oil and overall plastic industries all keep thriving because we all keep consuming. Try a zero-waste challenge! Stop consuming plastic or, rather, all unnecessary plastic. Refuse, Reduce, Reuse, Repair, Exchange, Borrow, Recycle, Compost. Try going vegetarian, change your red meats for fish or chicken instead; or try no meat days to start making a change. There are tons of options and ways to begin. Check out Bea Johnson, Lauren Singer, The Girl Gone Green, the documentary Minimalism: people are already doing different things to change. The people I mentioned have many things in common despite having different lifestyles: some are single, others have families, some live in houses, others in small apartments, some are completely vegan, some aren't, some changed for purely selfish or economic reasons, other thinking about the large-scale impact of their actions. I'm sure at least one of them will resonate with you. 
Let's educate ourselves and stop expecting others to make a change before we do. All our small actions ADD UP, both the positive and the negative ones.

text:
Yes it is so simple so obvious;   We must change the way we live.  We in the rich countries could stop eating meat and dairy and stop using fossil fuels tomorrow.  That would save the   earth and all the living beings that depend on the earth.  Its true that if we did that we would no longer be rich countries, our economies would fall apart;   but if we don't end the extravagance intentionally our unlawful way of life will bring us to utter ruin.  
     Only we the people can make the critical difference  not by protest but by changing the way we live.  It may seem like great personal sacrifice is required but in the end we will be happier.   I have been a vegetarian for fifty years, a vegan for 35 and a raw vegan for ten years.  I am a full time bicycle courier and in superb health with none of the health problems that plague most people at 74.
         I don't own a car and never will.  Cars not only contribute to climate change, they murder and maim those in their path and deaden their occupants.  To ride a bicycle, to run or to walk is connect with life and be filled by life.  So although it may seem hard in the transition, we our only sacrificing our unhappiness.
author: mark harris

text: Individual action like not flying, eating local and vegetarian food, insulating your house, etc are all very will but will never be enough. Groups like Extinction Rebellion (XR) are taking direct action to make our leaders wake up to the severity of the climate crisis. Everyone who watches this video should get involved with their local XR group, or if it doesn't exist yet, start one!

text:
I personally feel that the best way we can support Greta Thunberg and the other students who are not going to school on Fridays worldwide would be through "Fossil Fuel Free Fridays." 
By that I mean not buying any gasoline or other fossil fuels on Fridays.
It probably wouldn't take a lot of people doing it for there to be a signal that the fossil fuel companies would notice.
If enough people do it, then perhaps the fossil fuel companies could be persuaded to stop funding climate change deniers and to start supporting meaningful action to control climate change.
author: Keith McNeill

text:
There's absolutely no environmental benefit to being a raw vegan. To being vegan? Absolutely. But to be raw is not only pointless it's unsustainable as you have to consume far more calories in raw food (thus increasing your environmental footprint) to feel satiated where cooked (vegan) food would do the trick in far less quantities. Check out "unnatural vegan" channel about that subject. It's explained far better than I could.


Other than that I mostly agree with you.

text: luumus, please send me the post about raw food causing one to consume more calories.  I don't think it does but I'm open to the possibility.  However, whether eating more calories contributes to carbon footprint depends on how the food was grown..  if it is grown sustainably plant food  sequesters carbon by putting into the soil through the plant roots.  From there microbes turn it into humus which is the best method of carbon sequestration there is.   The chinese had a sustainable civilization for forty centuries using sustainable methods of agriculture.
author: mark harris

text: As a raw vegan I'm not against being vegan.  Quite the contrary I champion the vegan diet.  Raw vegan is just a refinement that some people choose,  usually after first having been purified in body by  being a whole foods vegan.

text:
¬†@Yo Mama¬† I don't know where you get the 15% reduction from. 
According to the recent IPCC report, if we want to hold the temperature to 1.5 degrees, we have to cut emissions by about 45% by 2030, and  be at net zero by 2050.
Divestment is a tool but only one. If we want to meet those goals we need to charge a fee for using fossil fuels, as in carbon fee-and-dividend.

text: This is so inspiring- but I am slightly disheartened to see people's comments below in some senses. The action she talks about is not just individuals becoming carbon neutral (and people arguing about ways to do that or what is more important than what). She chose to sit outside her parliament and talks so much about what governments around the world should be acting on and discussing. She wants us to lobby our governments so that ALL of us have to change. She talks of how much oil is used everyday and how there are no restrictions on the businesses that are complicit with this. We need to unite rather than get into a game of one-up-man-ship and get on the streets and lobby our governments on a local and national scale to make this work. we want to be effective in our activism. We all want the same thing- to survive. We need to unite to show people in power what we want. Evangelism (in whatever form) will not help us gain support..

text: Like she said, we have all the solutions. In some regions of the world, solar power + batteries are already cheaper than being on the grid, and where it isn't yet, solar is usually cheaper than fossil. All land transport can be converted to electric, powered by renewables, and we know how, but we need to share mobility to make the transition quick enough. It will also reduce the energy needed dramatically. Thermal management can be done much more efficiently with heat pumps. Buildings can be isolated and solar integrated. Short-range aircraft can be converted to electric too, long range aircraft to hydrogen (it is probably the hardest problem, since there is little potential in making them more efficient). Shipping in littoral waters can be done on a combination of wind and hydrogen. Large, heavy ships can use nuclear power, like carriers, ice breakers and submarines do today. We certainly need to reduce our meat consumption too. This is not a technological problem, we have all the technological solutions. The problem is that fossil fuels are so deeply integrated in societies that we are not confident enough to take the plunge, stop subsidizing them, and let new technologies be economical.

author: Felix Stanfield

text:
Beautiful. T  ruths spoken eloquently.  But, at the end, people stand up and clap and cheer - and then most of them drive home, eat meat the next day, continue as if they can't change anything so they won't bother. 

Although it's not easy, it IS possible to drastically change one's lifestyle. Admittedly I've been 'green' for 30+ years, but 10 years ago I took part in a competition to find the person i the UK with the lowest carbon footprint, and I won, with a figure just under a twelfth of the UK average. I don't live in a cave or wear a hair shirt - I'm self employed and use public transport and bike to travel to my work, I switched my household electricity to 100% renewables in 1999, I grow some of my own veg and cook veggie meals from simple ingredients. I'm not addicted to shopping and consuming - I prefer zero carbon pleasures, of which there are many.  Agreed not everyone would be able to live like me, but many could at least go part of the way there, but I see so few people trying. 

Will Greta's honest and direct impassioned speech change people's lives?  I hope so. She is one of the inspirations behind Extinction Rebellion, who are aiming to force governments worldwide to declare a Climate Emergency, to pledge to go zero carbon as soon as possible, and to try a new form of decisionmaking which would bypass the slow and often corrupt political procedures we have now.  Join us for positive peaceful change in Extinction Rebellion!

text: Well, hopefully you haven't bought it yet.  Do some research before you decide that an electric car is actually an improvement.  The in-depth studies I've seen suggest it's about the same as a fossil fueled counterpart, due to the massive amount of energy embodied in the production of the batteries.  Better yet, figure out how not to need a car, and live like 99.9% of our ancestors.  Granted, this is not a simple matter in today's society.  If you choose to do this through an urban existence (where everything is provided to you using fossil fuels, thus increasing your dependence), you've done nothing.  If you go rural, you'll need to meet more of your needs directly, but should have that ability.  Any travel, however, will be greater distances which make fossil fuels all the more appealing.   I've gone rural myself, and taught myself to use horses for transportation (not all that odd of a thing where I live, since Amish communities are nearby).  But I cannot make a living and use horse transportation exclusively, yet.
author: David Veale

text: With regards to flying... I once told my boss that I didn't think it was responsible in light of what's happening (I also had to fly for my career).  It clearly fell on deaf ears, but simply going out on a limb and stating this fact, if enough people tell your boss this, may eventually sway minds.
author: David Veale

text: ¬†@pjd412¬†  -- Whole lifecycle emissions studies I've read before say that an electric car powered by the "average" US grid sources is about the same as a conventional car.  I also found a link from the Union of Concerned Scientists (whom I greatly respect) suggesting that lifecycle emissions are about half those of a conventional ICU car.  So somewhere in there is the truth...  even if these cars are at half of the emissions of an ICU powered vehicle, that's still too much to stave off human extinction at this late stage, particularly when car use is still growing massively around the world.  We need to be at zero within 12 years (and that's probably still not enough imho).  Also... please keep in mind that there are no operational fleets of electric heavy trucks in anywhere in the world.  It's too much of an engineering challenge to make them cheap enough to be competitive.   The answer, of course, is to return to a system which we know to work, and which is in fact zero carbon without question.  That's to de-industrialize.
author: David Veale

text:

You'd be amazed!
Good on you for the electric car! Consider sharing it with your neighbours. Even better than everyone limiting their driving and owning a car is everyone limiting their driving while sharing a car. The emissions benefit per produced electric car is not very large if it is not used efficiently.

text: GREAT! BUT kinda ironic that this TedX site hosts another 'lecture' by a lady who notes that the one topic people seem afraid to talk about is overpopulation... so, 'are you fixed' so that you do not spawn more children?' It is also not about what you eat but what the demands will be for what our human locusts will need to eat to survive... consumption of beans as a 'vegetarian diet'.... hmm... in mine, more 'flatulence'. So, the vegan and vegetarian will espouse 'eating veggies' while the numbers of vegetarians grows and grows in places that are already primarily 'vegetarian', like India. More people equals more 'human locusts' of consumption... it is not about what we eat but about how WE are replacing all animal life on this planet by our consumption of EVERYTHING and there is less discussion about the flatulence WE are causing even if we shift from 'eating those flatulent cows and their byproducts'... WE need to start doing some simple math here and start declaring that WE will make one person or NO PERSON families OUR voluntary life goals. I was told in 1967, by my geography teacher that overpopulation WAS the primary problem facing the planet in the next 20 years... we are past that... my spouse wanted to have a third child. I had a son and daughter and refused to add to the world burden anymore... BUT rock stars like Mick Jagger will have ANOTHER child with a 20-something and there will be NO CONDEMNATION (he has fathered how many, is it 8???) We will condemn the masses of poor in India, etc. BUT not set example ourselves. I had a vascectomy in 1981 because Canada made it free and I felt it my moral obligation, for a wife who had suffered through two horrendous births (and still wanted a third baby... something I will never understand) and for what were clearer and clearer as growing population pressures on this planet... so, let's make this less about what we eat (although I am vegetarian now for reasons more than the distress caused to other living mammals) and more about social responsibilities all around... Don MacAlpine... a former forest scientist from Nipigon, Ontario Canada, now living in Wolseley, Saskatchewan Canada

text: And how do you plan to grow food without chemical fertilizer, diesel fuel, and livestock manure?  Granted, I think hunter-gatherer is the gold standard, but we've got a long way to travel before we get there.   A de-industrialized agricultural system absolutely requires the use of livestock for both traction and manure as fertilizer.  I've been doing this for 10 years now, because there's a historical model to follow that works!
author: David Veale

text: Feeding livestock vast amounts of food just to have fertilizer is ridiciolous. Protein obtained from animals require far more resources than plants alone and produces more waste. That's why we need to change our diets. Why do you imply that we need to go back? We need to move forward and take actions which won't put that much strain on planet's ecosystem as today's do. People are succeding with compost fertilizers made entirely from plant waste. We can learn from history but we can also learn from nowness. I think we need both.
author: Wo.

text:
Wo. -- feeding livestock massive amounts of grain is, of course ridiculous, and was not done before the advent of the fossil-fueled combine.  Putting them on grassland, however, allows us to utilize land that would be useless for growing crops, and there's far more of that type of terrain than there is of high-quality farmland.  Not only that, but the grazing, and the constant growth/dieback of the grass roots as grazing occurs, sequesters massive amounts of carbon and is what created the best soils on the planet.  

The models which humans have followed for much of our existence before industrialization are both low to zero carbon, and demonstrated to work.  A symbiosis with our fellow creatures is anything but moving "backwards".  

Have you ever considered how your vegan farms will fertilize?   I have, because I grow the majority of my own food.  I can assure you that crop yields in the absence of fertilizer are so pathetic that they're likely to not be worth growing in many places.  I can also assure you that aside from chemically produced fertilizer, you're not going to have an adequate quantity of fertilizer without livestock.

Now show me someone who runs a farm without fossil fuel inputs, and produces adequate compost without fossil fuels, and I may be impressed.   I've yet to see one.
author: David Veale

text: ¬†@David Veale¬† Look into permaculture.
author: Anton

text:
¬†@Anton¬† -- I have.  I've been an avid forager since I was old enough to venture outside, and am a former forester, currently farmer (I'm 46 now).  I'm quite familiar with how vegetative succession works and what species are useful, and how reliable such harvests are.  Ultimately, we'll all be hunter/gatherers again if we survive the bottleneck we've created for ourselves.  Though such cultures didn't really know the word "permaculture", they typically practiced it.  

So, I think you're on to something -- long term, once we've returned to normal population density, if we manage to make it there.  Shorter term, however, intensive agriculture, practiced entirely without fossil fuels, will be a required step, because the quantity of food produced per unit of land area will still be considerably greater.  

Such practices will by no means support 7.7 billion people, but they might support a billion, and with time, our biosphere may recover.  Once that happens, large scale permaculture becomes an option.

Or we stop just listening and admiring courageous individuals like Greta, who delivered a stunning and abashing settlement of accounts  at this sad joke of a Climate Change Conference at Katowice (watch that one. If you liked this one, Katowice will leave you speechless).
It's about time for all of us to stop being victims and take action. Refuse to carry on like sheep running into the abyss and leaving it all to the politicians, and corporates, and capitalist billionaires etc. No more - let's get connected and realize: We got the power, if we just unite our efforts which today thanks modern connectivity is easier than ever before in the history of mankind. author: Oliver Alex

text: ¬†@Cerenade Me¬†--  Go Vegan is a simplistic solution at best.  Go de-industrial is the only option that produces any chance of continued survival, and quite frankly, there are no pre-industrial vegan societies.  I applaud the effort to avoid industrially produced animal products, but livestock are a critical component of basic agriculture, or wildlife are a critical component of the hunter-gatherer diet.
author: David Veale

text: ¬†@David Veale¬† we don't need animal products to survive . In fact we thrive without them. The US spends the most on health care for chronic diseases brought on by industrialized food and animal products. Everyone is too blind to see the truth and buts the propaganda sold to them. Going vegan would reduce emissions in half overnight
author: sandray

text:
¬†@sandray¬† While we may do better without industrially produced animal products (the vast majority of which are grain-based), we simply cannot farm on a de-industrial scale without the aid of animals.  I'm already doing that to the extent that I'm able.  Horses provide the power to harvest hay (thus feeding themselves as well as other animals), plow, cultivate, and perform various other tasks such as hauling firewood.

I fear that our society, in rejection of industrial methods (and rightly so!) has grown so far removed from the natural world that some would willingly throw out the very things we would need to survive -- such as effective traditional methods of agriculture.  I can speak from experience, that the original sort of pre-industrial agriculture is far more of a symbiosis than that which you will see in CAFOs or conventional operations.  

I'd be interested to know your ideas... have you ever grown the majority of your food?  Could you do so without fossil fuels?  Could you do so without draft animals?  How would you fertilize?  I've been down this road far enough to answer all of these questions for myself, and as a one-time vegetarian, animal welfare figures prominently in my philosophy.
author: David Veale

text: ¬†@David Veale¬† I live in an urban environment, so I'm not a farmer. I do grow my own vegetables in my backyard but with such a tiny space it isn't enough to sustain me and my family.  Understand that it may mean a farmer would need the support of animals, but whether the farming is industrialized or not, there is no argument for animal agriculture.  Plants are the way to go for our health, the environment, the animals, species extinction, pollution, climate change, etc.  Even Greta herself has gone vegan for this very reason. It is a no brainer
author: sandray

text:
¬†@sandray¬† How many pre-industrial societies were vegan?   None, to my knowledge.  Is it possible to be de-industrialized and vegan?  Perhaps, but I doubt it.  Animals have always provided far more than just food for us.  Fossil fuels have given us an unwarranted sense of invincibility, to the point that we have the luxury of rejecting that which we deem immoral (and we should reject industrial agriculture as immoral!).  If we keep using fossil fuels, we go extinct, and have likely already set that process in motion for ourselves.  If we drop them, I think we're going to need to use everything we can get (and then some).  

I also lived in an urban environment for much of my life.  The whole urban arrangement (assuming a town of more than a few thousand), while it does offer some advantages, is ultimately dependent upon fossil fuels.  While I certainly can't fault someone for living in an urban area, I don't recommend it for this very reason.

I'm not trying to point fingers with urban vs. rural, but simply pointing out that I've given these matters a great deal of thought, to a depth of which is probably not achievable without actually doing the things I've done.
author: David Veale

text: ¬†@David Veale¬† I walk and ride my bike everywhere. No need for a vehicle unless I need a large item like a couch which is rare. A car is not a necessity in the city, but IS in the country and suburbs. So what if there isn't a pre industrial society that wasn't vegan? There could be now. I don't need to rely on what was in the past to define a future state. That is part of our problem now.  No one can adapt or think outside the box
author: sandray

text:
¬†@sandray¬† -- that's exactly how I lived when I was urban.  It was fantastic, and kept me in shape, though I can cite a handful of times when I was nearly killed by car drivers.  I know people who weren't so lucky (one of whom suffered significant brain damage).  Though it's nice to have, a car is no more a requirement for rural people now than it was 150 years ago.  If you go to an area developed before the advent of the car, you'll find that most towns are no more than 10 miles apart -- making 10 miles round-trip the maximum you'd have to travel by horse, which is very doable (20 miles is about the max without stopping).  Horse transportation was, and is, still quite possible.  It's made easier where I live by the fact that many Amish are nearby, and I thus have easy access to harness shops.  In areas with more severe weather (I'm currently in Michigan, formerly was near Seattle), a bicycle is much less viable due to ice and snow.

Also, while we think of our energy use mostly in terms of direct use, the vast majority is used industrially and for public infrastructure.  Without it, roads will soon decay due to lack of concrete and asphalt.  Without a road (or access to spares for a bicycle or a buggy), horses again become the best option aside from our own two feet.
author: David Veale

text: ¬†@David Veale¬† If we were all using horses for transportation then more reason to have a plant only diet, due to the amount of animal poop to deal with. Lol. Bikes could work rural as well if cars were reduced significantly.  That's how China functioned for years, and Cuba still does to a certain extent.  More bikes, less cars would be a win.
author: sandray

text: ‚Äã¬†@sandray¬† Yes, they do make poop!  My three horses (two Belgians, one Standardbred) fill about two wheelbarrows full each day.  I'm headed out for scooping in just a few minutes, in fact.  But -- it's not the problem as most people imagine it to be now that virtually none of us grow our own food.  It's a fantastic fertilizer, of which anyone needing to grow food (i.e. all of us, at some point in the not too distant future) will be fighting to acquire.

author: Lukes Army Sydney NSW Australia

text:
Xrisus94 so your reasoning is flawed. Yes, carbon emissions and oil consumption of heavy transport vehicles, ships and aircraft is a major contributor to the problem. But the original poster wasn‚Äôt saying that livestock are the only problem. He was merely saying they‚Äôre an enormous problem. Waiting to attack this issue all in one go will result in us waiting forever. You can eat less, or no meat, even though it still comes at an environmental cost - offset the damage by maximizing opportunity costs towards reducing climate change, as opposed to increasing profits at the expense of climate.

It‚Äôs possible to deal with the livestock issue and the transportation issue at the same time. It‚Äôs not either or. Engineers are working hard to make green engines for all craft. Transport companies would LOVE to be rid of oil because it costs them all arms and legs. Green engines will be a monumental reduction in cost for them. My point is: it‚Äôs coming. They‚Äôre working on it. 

In the meantime, you can stop eating meat, or eat much less, because that‚Äôs something you can do right now. And you can also become an active citizen to place pressure on your political representatives to free themselves from the fossil fuel industry corruption that currently owns governments worldwide through bribes and barely legal incentives.

text:
Here's a fun fact ‚Äî ALL types of agriculture (that includes the meat industry as well) only count for about 9% of all co2 emissions, whereas transportation and electricity count for 28% EACH. 

Think about that for a moment.

You don't have to be vegan to be green. Just think twice before bying a new phone, or booking that flight to Thailand. Maybe don't buy new clothes all the time, and mend the ones that are torn. Recycle. Remember not to leave lights on in rooms you aren't using. Shower instead of bathing. If you live in a house, get solar panels. Take public transportation when possible. Get food that was produced as closely to where you live as possible. And yes, maybe eat a bit less meat. Don't have to cut it out of your diet entierly, but think of ways to eat less of it. 

I think if everyone did these kinds of things, it would add up, and perhaps even make a great difference.

text: I have been communicating with Greta while she was in Poland since I agree.  I am pushing the Windyday Concept where every city will build worker cooperative owned factories to build batteries and solar panels.  At the same time there will be training of youth for jobs to install sun and wind energy projects, as well as to build and repair EV, as well as to convert ICEV to EV.  Each city with a factory has to feet it's workers so we need local food farms as well as planting hemp.  Hemp can replace plastic and is 7 times better as a CO2 trap than trees.  I almost succeeded in getting the factory started but there was a snag with having to also install a wind turbine.  The corruption of the European Electricity Grid as well as the sinister practices of the Oil Lobby in Switzerland put a jackboot down on this project.  I thought that with the move of the climate scientists around COP24 would see a change.  I don't know how many cities I have written but I am also getting a little tired of talk. text:
Areliagh Where does it say they shouldn‚Äôt applaud? Your understanding of my point is narrow. I explicitly say that liberal elites enjoy feeling good when they applaud what they believe is virtuous, but once they leave the venue there‚Äôs no real action on their part. Greta highlights this too. So of course they should/can applaud, but their action is more important than anything else. Liberal elites love applauding the right causes, but that‚Äôs usually where it stops. 

I‚Äôm a Vegan, for a start. We recycle 90% of our waste. We reuse as much water as we can. Our entire garden consists of succulents that don‚Äôt require much water at all. 1 of our 2 cars is green. We‚Äôre almost completely paperless in our home. 

You?

text:
Pieter Howes Great that you keep going into the right direction. Only one thing: green cars do not exist. The production of one car itself destroys approximately 70-90 metric tons of natural resources. 20% of the co2 emissions of its lifecycle-co2 emissions emerge at its production. 
It‚Äôs much more disastrous for electric cars. You can only see green cars if you watch The Flintstones :)

text: I‚Äôm very glad you asked Sir Charles. We‚Äôre all angry at the current situation aren‚Äôt we? Or at least fed up. I‚Äôm part of a small team who (may!) have found a way out of this mess. And I don‚Äôt just mean the climate mess, I mean all of it. Consumerism, war, corruption, poverty, hunger, land exploitation, all of it. The common thread that runs through these things is the pursuit to accumulate (fictional) profits. But we have found a way to use all that capitalist momentum to render wealth accumulation moot, effectively eliminating the root cause of the vast majority of the world‚Äôs problems. The real beauty is that it‚Äôs a reorganization of accounting and business practice we use now anyway, and the more capitalism fights against it the more it contributes to its own demise. We use its own momentum. The net result is an array of solutions to problems that no longer exist. We have a few more experts to run this by to work out some nuances and then begin putting into practice in the new year. It may not seem like it but our society is just millimeters from being turned around. If anyone is interested to know more we can find a secure way to share contact information and I can invite you to a webinar.

text:
While Earth's warming phase can be slowed down; and it is at least worth it to the improve air quality, it can never be completely stopped by human action alone. The Earth will still warm up and things will still be rough for future generations; even if it happens at a slower rate at that point. The Earth will always go through extreme heating and cooling cycles; neither. 

Slowing down Earth's warming phase is somewhat achievable; but it is foolish to think Earth will NEVER warm up ever again on its own.

text:
Why are you bringing the "left" to this issue. The so called "left" is also virtually hopeless about tackling this problem, actually not a single  influential leader in the whole planet is taking this seriously.
The cultists are the ones who believe that burning hundreds of millions of years worth of oil is somehow a "good" thing and that plants will thrive. Do yo not see how simplistic and foolish that way of thinking is?
Plants have adapted to much lower co2 levels, what they need is a STABLE CLIMATE with regular predictable rainfall rates and temperatures which is what is now changing rapidly and leading to a cascade of extinctions of all kinds of insects and animals that decimate whole ecosystems.
Also, it has been shown that some, crops do better with high co2 leves (in lab settings) but at the cost of much lower nutrient densities and they require much higher levels of other nutrients to sustain that growth.

text:
¬†@Agus¬† 
You looked up the science of my statement for the first time and saw its true, i can tell. This is all a hoax!!!
author: Megaman Vile

text:
¬†@Megaman Vile¬† I did look up the science and that's why I said that some crops grow better in "lab controlled settings" with higher co2 levels. 
Did you know that we can breath oxygen at higher levels too? And yes, we can "thrive" for a little bit but constantly breathing too high oxygen levels will eventually burn our lungs, reduce our blood hematocyte levels and really screw up our bodies, and this is oxygen we are talking about here....
Too much of a "good" thing can be bad for you, is that so hard to understand? Why don't you drink 10 gallons of water per day if it's such a "good" thing?
You cant massively change co2 levels of the planet and expect nature to just "thrive", plants need a lot more than just co2 just as you need a lot more than just oxygen to be healthy. They need insects to pollinate, they need nitrogen, phosphorus and other minerals, regular water and moisture levels and very precise temperature ranges.
Climate change completely screws up all those things so in this case too much co2 is BAD.
author: Agus

text:
¬†@Agus¬† 
I've seen people in high oxygen environments and they have high performance. All you need to know is the earth is balanced.

Try breathing high oxygen levels for months and years and see what happens to your body, you die an agonizing  death. Why because higher oxygen levels equals higher oxygen free radicals that require higher antioxidant levels in your body to neutralize. Our bodies require extremely complex antioxidant defenses to "handle" oxygen, that's why a lot of bacteria that lack those defenses are extremely vulnerable to oxygen and will die even with minute levels.

Your are contradicting yourself with your last statement, you said the earth is "balanced" but yet you are saying it "needs" higher co2 levels?  So we are disturbing that "balance" aren't we? We went from sub 300 ppm gobal co2 to around 410 and heading rapidly to 500ppm and more. Where is the balance in that? We need exactly what you said, we need things to be "balanced" if you stop contradicting yourself you may be getting somewhere with that line of thought.

text:
Warming planet does benefit some crops until a certain temperature. The destabilized climate patterns will reduce output. Areas along the equator and sub tropics already have difficulty growing certain crops. Global temperatures higher than 2C will drastically reduce grain output and for every degree rise grain production reduces by 10%. Warmer temperatures can also give way to invasive pests.

CO2 is part of the photosynthesis, and whoever doesn't know probably forgot about it in elementary school. There are problems with the narrative. 
- Increasing CO2 speeds up growth of some plants and this can reduce their nutritional value. 
- CO2 only benefits plants if there is sufficient water and if they aren't saturated, and there will be less consistency of precipitation and less of it reaching inland because of our pollution and deforestation. 
- We've increased CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere by 60ppm over the last 30 years, in addition to land and ocean intake.. So the conditions and species vary as to whether or not they will benefit, at least in the short term agriculture and plant life is expected to benefit. But I should let you know that the short term is getting shorter - less than a decade shorter. Understand that any drastic changes to the chemistry of our atmosphere and oceans will impose problems.

 Increased concentrations of CO2 by hundreds of ppm reduces cognitive ability. Maybe you should open a window.

text:
Poor little girl, very eloquent, but she didn't do her homework. Brainwashed into terror by selected UN ''climatologists''. They're targeting our kids with a story to own them to achieve their globalist goals. Who else did that throughout history? (Give me your kids for five years and the seeds I've sown...) 

THAT SAID, the majority of climate scientists are not UN-funded and are ignored because their findings are not in line with the ''Global Warming'' theorists. It's so bad that now, UN is talking about ''Climate Change'' and no longer warming. 

On that level, they would be correct. Climate has been evolving since planet Earth came into being and there's not a damn thing we can do about it, only adapt as we always have. A few hundred years ago, we went through another Little Ice Age and apparently, we're heading back to same. 

P.S.: What would be so bad about the climate warming up another 1 Celsius? Species will not die from that. We would have a slightly longer agricultural timeline to feed the sadly ever-expanding human population, the latter being the major problem. Regards to all.

author: Tidepool Clipper

text:
‚Äã¬†@Tidepool Clipper¬† Humans have not "sped" the warming. The earth should have been cooling actually as we slowly move to the cooling phase of the orbital milankovitch cycle and the sun is in a very low activity solar cycle at the moment ie. maunder minimum which should have accelerated that natural cooling phase but we are heating up faster and faster. That means that we are more than 100% to blame on this because of our greenhouse gas emissions of Co2, Methane and nitrous oxide and that effect is so large that it not only completely negates all of the natural cooling mechanisms but is actually creating unprecedented levels of warming in the arctic especially.

You are right about the fact that we can only slow the warming and not stop it, massive amounts of energy per day, around 500 times more than all the energy humanity consumes per year has been and is increasingly being transferred to the oceans and they have been charging with heat like a huge battery. It will take hundreds of years or millennia to re-normalize the earths climatic system even if we completely stopped all emissions. But there is much more at stake than that, if we don't tackle this cataclysm with all our resources the heating could be so high as to cause a massive extinction level event like what happened at the End Permian extinction 256 million years ago or the PETM thermal maximum 55 million years ago.

We will not stop significant levels of warming but we can and absolutely should at all costs stop warming that is of a degree so high that it can threaten the extinction of most life on earth including humans if it is able to destabilize the massive methane in the arctic permafrost and underwater hydrates that would increase the greenhouse gasses magnitudes higher than what we have already released. The idea here is to stop a massive chain reaction before it has time to ignite and move completely away from our hands. This is what's really at stake!
author: Agus
